EMRLD Borrower LP, a Delaware limited partnership (the “Issuer”), and Emerald Co-Issuer Inc., a direct subsidiary of the Issuer (the “Co-Issuer” and, together with the Issuer,
the “Issuers”), are offering $950,000,000 aggregate principal amount of their      % senior secured notes due 2031 (the “notes”). The notes will bear interest at a rate of      %
per annum. The Issuers will pay interest on the notes semi-annually in cash in arrears on       and       of each year, beginning on     , 2025.  The notes will mature
on     , 2031.

The Issuers intend to use the proceeds of this offering and borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility (as defined herein), together with cash on hand, to repurchase, pursuant
to the Note Purchase Agreement (as defined herein), certain unsecured notes issued by the Seller Notes Issuer (as defined herein) to subsidiaries of Emerson Electric Co.
(“Emerson”) having an aggregate principal amount of $2,345.0 million (the “Seller Notes”) (such repurchase of the Seller Notes, the “Seller Notes Repurchase”) and/or for general
corporate purposes and to pay fees, costs and expenses related to this offering.

Unless the Seller Notes Repurchase is consummated simultaneously with this offering, the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds from this offering into
an escrow account for the notes for the benefit of the holders of the notes. The release of the escrowed funds will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions (as defined herein)
set forth in the Escrow Agreement (as defined herein). If the consummation of the Seller Notes Repurchase does not occur on or prior to the Outside Date (as defined herein) or if
the Issuer notifies the Escrow Agent (as defined herein) that, in its reasonable judgment, the Seller Notes Repurchase will not be consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or
that the Note Purchase Agreement has been terminated, the Issuer must redeem the notes on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein) at the Special Mandatory
Redemption Price (as defined herein), pursuant to the terms of the indenture that will govern the notes. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Gross Proceeds; Special Mandatory
Redemption.”

At any time prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may redeem some or all of the notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes to be redeemed, plus
a make-whole premium, together with accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time on or after     , 2027, the Issuers may redeem
some or all of the notes at the applicable redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date.
In addition, at any time prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes with an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds
from certain equity offerings at the redemption price set forth in this offering memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. In
addition, at any time prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes during each calendar year following the issuance of
the notes at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount of the notes to be redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See
“Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.”

The notes will be guaranteed, jointly and severally, by EMRLD Guarantor LP, a Delaware limited partnership (“Holdings”), the direct parent of the Issuer, and each of the Issuer’s
wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries (the “guarantors”) that guarantee our Senior Secured Credit Facilities (as defined herein) (other than the Co-Issuer) (the
“guarantees”). The notes and guarantees (i) will be secured on a senior priority basis by security interests in the Fixed Asset Priority Collateral (as defined herein) and on a junior
priority basis by security interests in the ABL Priority Collateral (as defined herein), in each case, subject to certain limitations and permitted liens and (ii) will rank equally in
right of payment with all of the Issuers’ and the guarantors’ senior indebtedness, without giving effect to collateral arrangements, and effectively equal to all of the Issuers’ and
the guarantors’ senior indebtedness secured on the same priority basis as the notes, including our Term Loan Facilities (as defined herein). The notes and the guarantees will be
effectively subordinated to any of the Issuers’ and the guarantors’ (i) indebtedness that is secured by assets that do not constitute collateral for the notes to the extent of the value
of the assets securing such indebtedness and (ii) indebtedness that is secured by a senior-priority lien, including our Revolving Credit Facility, to the extent of the value of the
ABL Priority Collateral. The notes and the guarantees will be effectively senior to any of the Issuers’ and guarantors’ unsecured indebtedness, to the extent of the value of the
assets securing the notes. The notes and the guarantees will be structurally subordinated to the indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of any
subsidiary of the Issuer (other than the Co-Issuer) that is not a guarantor of the notes. See “Description of Notes—Security for the Notes.”

**Non-GAAP Financial Measures**

We use Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow to better
evaluate and manage the performance of our business and make resource allocation decisions as they provide greater
understanding with respect to the results of our operations. Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin,
Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash
Flow, Adjusted Free Cash Flow and combined year ended September 30, 2023 financial data and twelve months
March 31, 2024 data, are supplemental measures that are not required by or presented in accordance with GAAP.

We evaluate our operating performance using a metric we refer to as Adjusted EBITDA. We define
Adjusted EBITDA as net earnings adjusted for interest, income tax, depreciation and amortization (“EBITDA”) as
further adjusted to exclude certain items that impact the comparison of the performance of our businesses either
period-over-period or with other businesses as more fully described below. Adjusted EBITDA Margin is calculated
as Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales for the respective period. Standalone Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as
Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted for estimated standalone costs assuming we were an independent company for
the entire applicable period. We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as Standalone Adjusted EBITDA further
adjusted for the estimated normalized “run-rate” benefit from pricing actions and cost savings initiatives that are
expected to be realized by the end of fiscal 2026. We present these further adjustments because they are a permitted
addback in the indenture that will govern the notes and the credit agreements that govern our Senior Secured Credit
Facilities, and they should not be viewed as a projection of future performance. We cannot assure you that any or all
of these cost savings will be achieved in the anticipated amounts or within the anticipated timeframes or at all. See
“Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Transactions—We may not realize the anticipated cost savings from the
Transactions.” Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin is calculated as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA divided by net
sales for the respective period. We use Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted
EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin to compare our operating results
on a consistent basis.

We present Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin because we believe they assist investors and analysts
in comparing our performance across reporting periods on a consistent basis by excluding items that we do not
believe are indicative of our core operating performance, and we believe that these metrics provide useful
information to investors in understanding and evaluating our operating results. Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA


-----

Margin do not reflect certain cash expenses that we are obligated to make, and although depreciation and
amortization are non-cash charges, assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the
future, and Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements.

We define Free Cash Flow as cash provided by operating activities less capital expenditures. We define
Adjusted Free Cash Flow as Free Cash Flow less partnership distributions. We use Free Cash Flow and Adjusted
Free Cash Flow to evaluate our ability to generate cash that can be used for working capital requirements, interest,
repayment of indebtedness, member distributions, acquisitions, and for continued re-investment into our business.

Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow are not
measurements of financial performance or liquidity under GAAP. In evaluating our performance as measured by
these metrics, management recognizes and considers the limitations of these measures. Other companies in our
industry may calculate Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow differently
than we do or may not calculate them at all, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these
limitations, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow should not be
considered in isolation or as substitutes for net earnings or any other measure calculated in accordance with GAAP,
as applicable, and should be considered together with our GAAP financial measures and the reconciliations to the
corresponding GAAP financial measures set forth in this offering memorandum.

**Basis of Presentation and Other Information**

This offering memorandum presents the historical consolidated and combined financial and other data of
the Climate Technologies business (the “Climate Technologies Business”) held by Emerald JV Holdings L.P., a
Delaware limited partnership (“JV NewCo”) following the closing of the transactions (the “Transactions”)
contemplated by the Transaction Agreement entered into on October 30, 2022 (collectively, the “Acquisition”) by
and among Emerson Electric Co., a Missouri Corporation (“Emerson”), BCP Emerald Aggregator L.P., a Delaware
limited partnership (“BCP Emerald”) formed by affiliates of investment funds managed by affiliates of Blackstone
Inc. (“Blackstone”), Emerald Debt Merger Sub L.L.C. and JV NewCo. All references to fiscal years in this offering
memorandum, unless otherwise noted, refer to our fiscal years, which end on September 30.

As a result of the Transactions, a new basis of accounting was created on May 31, 2023. Accordingly, the
financial statements included elsewhere herein are separately presented for the periods before and after the
application of the new basis of accounting. The consolidated and combined financial statements of the Climate
Technology Business prior to the consummation of the Transactions on May 31, 2023, for the years ended
September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2022 and the period from October 1, 2022 to May 31, 2023 (the
“Predecessor Period”), reflect the financial position and operating results of the Climate Technologies Business
(collectively, the “Predecessor”) prior to completing the Transactions. The period commencing on May 31, 2023
(the “Successor Period”), reflects the financial position and operating results of JV NewCo and its consolidated
subsidiaries (collectively, the “Successor”) subsequent to the completion of the Transactions. Consequently, the
financial position and operating results of the Successor period are not comparable in certain respects to the financial
position and operating results of the Predecessor period. Under GAAP, we are required to present separately our
operating results of the Predecessor period ended May 31, 2023 and the Successor period. In certain instances, we
have supplemented the Predecessor and Successor period reporting with combined 2023 financial results to facilitate
a comparative discussion of the financial results for applicable periods. This combined 2023 financial data is not
required by nor presented in accordance with GAAP. They are a simple addition of Predecessor and Successor
periods and do not include any forms of adjustment.

Prior to the Transactions, the Climate Technologies Business historically operated as part of Emerson and
not as a standalone entity. The audited consolidated and combined financial statements for the years ended


-----

September 30, 2022 and September 30, 2021 of the Climate Technologies Business, and included in this offering
memorandum, present the historical financial position, results of operations and cash flows of the Climate
Technologies Business as if it had operated on a standalone basis subject to Emerson’s control and include all
accounts of the Climate Technologies Business and its subsidiaries and affiliates on a consolidated basis.
Intercompany transactions, profits and balances among Climate Technologies Business entities have been eliminated
in consolidation and combination. The consolidated and combined financial statements included in this offering
memorandum for the Predecessor Period were derived from Emerson’s financial statements and accounting records
and have been prepared in conformity with GAAP. Sale and purchase transactions between the Climate
Technologies Business and other Emerson affiliates for the Predecessor Period are included in the consolidated and
combined financial statements.

As a business of Emerson, prior to the closing of the Transactions, the Climate Technologies Business was
historically charged for costs directly related to its business and was allocated a portion of Emerson’s general
corporate costs. All of these costs are reflected in the consolidated and combined financial statements for the
Predecessor Period. Prior to the closing of the Transactions, the Climate Technologies Business participated in
various Emerson programs which included information technology services, employee benefits, medical insurance
and other programs. Costs associated with these programs were charged to the Climate Technologies Business based
on Emerson’s actual cost and the Climate Technologies Business’ relative level of usage.

**Our Company**

We are a leading global manufacturer of mission critical compressors, controls, components and solutions
to the heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration (“HVACR”) market. We provide products that help
enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create
environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Key components in an HVACR ecosystem include the compressor,
controls, the condenser and the evaporator. We provide best-in-class compressors, controls, components and
solutions for residential, commercial, industrial and transportation applications. We are the largest global
manufacturer in our served markets with approximately 40% share in overall global compression, including
approximately 70% in the North America residential heating, ventilation and air conditioning (“HVAC”) segment,
and strong positions within our non-compression offerings.

Our large installed base of more than 150 million HVAC compressor units globally drives profitable
aftermarket sales due to replacement dynamics, with approximately 80% of our net sales tied to repair or
replacement activity. Ongoing technology leadership is a key driver of our ability to capitalize on the replacement
cycle, as each successive generation of compressor provides greater cost savings, energy efficiency and higher levels
of environmental sustainability impact.

The replacement cycle is primarily driven by repair and replacement of HVACR systems. Our installed
base provides a foundation for ongoing earnings resilience as systems age and require repair or replacement. Global
regulations around the impact of refrigerants on global warming and the need for energy efficiency amplify
replacement dynamics in our business. Globally, government programs and incentives support the adoption of new,
more sustainable products creating a strong forward looking growth environment. Secular trends tied to human
health and comfort, as well as food quality, safety and sustainability drive additional demand for our compression
and solutions offerings.

As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a
small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential
HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the compressor has a mission-critical impact on function and
efficiency. Compressors enable the separation of the low-pressure side of an HVAC system, where heat is absorbed
into the refrigerant, from the high-pressure side of the system, where heat is discharged from the refrigerant to a
cooling medium (typically the ambient outside air). The compressor mechanically reduces the volume of low-side
refrigerant, thereby increasing its pressure and enabling heated refrigerant to flow to the high-pressure side of the
system, where it is cooled.


-----

We offer a variety of compressor technologies to meet customer-specific applications. Compression
technology is essential to improving system efficiency. In addition, refrigerant selection is dependent on rigorous
testing by compressor manufacturers to evaluate for performance and reliability and approve for use. Globally, the
HVACR system manufacturers are dependent upon compressor innovation to meet regulations for efficiency and
more environmentally friendly refrigerants. Because compressors are highly engineered to meet our customers’
technical requirements, we work closely with them on engineering, research and development (“ER&D”) efforts to
develop technology that meets consumer needs and complies with regulatory changes. These tightly coupled
relationships result from our industry leadership and help provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market
needs and opportunities to differentiate ourselves.

**Environmental Sustainability**

We believe compressors lie at the nexus of energy efficiency, helping build environmental sustainability
and playing a role in ESG-related trends. Environmental sustainability is inherently embedded in what we do, as we
enable our customers to set environmental sustainability goals and consistently meet or exceed ever-increasing
sustainability standards. The best compressors—the most energy efficient, the quietest, the most reliable—are also
the most environmentally sustainable and the most cost efficient for our original equipment manufacturer (“OEM”)
customers and the end users of their products. Consistently improving energy efficiency and sustainability requires
continued technological innovation which is made possible by our extensive and proven ER&D capabilities.


-----

with three world areas included within the HVACR Technologies group (HVACR Americas, HVACR AMEA
(Asia, Middle-East and Africa) and HVACR Europe).

EBITDA of $4,722.7 million and $1,361.0 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Consolidated and
Combined Financial Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to net earnings, the closest
comparable GAAP measure.

**_HVACR Technologies_**

The businesses within our HVACR Technologies group are leading producers of compression and related
controls and solutions for residential, commercial, refrigeration, industrial, and transport markets. Our pioneering
leadership of the scroll type of compressor enables foundational leadership across a majority of our served markets.
To meet the diverse needs of other compressor applications, we also provide hermetic, semi-hermetic, centrifugal,
screw and reciprocating compressors. The depth and breadth of our portfolio is unmatched globally, allowing us to
steward market change and innovation across a wide range of market segments and applications. Our global
HVACR Technologies group generated 84% of our total net sales and 87% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last
twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

**HVACR Americas is our largest business unit and operates within an environment where our scroll**
technology is extremely well-suited for applications across the served market. This business unit generated 57% of
our total net sales and 59% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our leading
positions with the largest North American OEMs serving the residential, commercial and transportation segments is
augmented by our leadership with a more fragmented set of refrigeration and industrial customers. Above and
beyond the growth that an accelerated energy efficiency and low GWP refrigerant regulatory environment is driving
for our core residential, commercial and refrigeration markets, our industrial business is well-positioned for
sustainability-driven growth within the renewable natural gas (“RNG”) segment. The industrial business is roughly
divided 50/50 between traditional industrial refrigeration applications and RNG applications. The RNG space is
growing at a double-digit compound annual growth rate the past few years and growth is expected to accelerate
given sustainability trends and the associated policies and incentives to deal with landfill and other off-gassing,
largely farm-digestor applications. We are well-positioned with key customers in this space, as well as with their
solution providers and engineering contractors. Broad heating, cooling and refrigeration needs across the Americas
region coupled with a mature regulatory environment provide a solid foundation for continued growth and
innovation opportunities.


-----

Our leadership in HVACR AMEA is driven by balanced sales between residential, commercial and
refrigeration applications. Our technology leadership in commercial, district and other heating and refrigeration
segments in China is complemented by our broad leadership positions in the rest of the region, including high
ambient temperature and residential applications in countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. HVACR AMEA
generated 18% of our net sales and 22% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

**HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest**

**_Electronics and Controls_**

Our Electronics and Controls business unit is a global leader in cold chain controls, monitoring solutions
and climate control products and solutions. We provide building and refrigeration controls and monitoring solutions
for food retail and foodservice applications, refrigerated container and perishable cargo monitoring solutions for
cargo and marine applications and healthcare environmental safety monitoring solutions. Our business benefits from
sustainability, energy management and digitalization tailwinds, including integrated refrigeration solutions across
compressors and controls, market penetration opportunities with leading automation capabilities, expanding data
services and analytics in cargo monitoring, and healthcare monitoring and grid-connected energy management
solutions. We also provide traditional and connected thermostats, energy and building management solutions, gas
valves, cooling controls and control electronics. Our business benefits from energy efficiency, connectivity and
control tailwinds, including opportunities to support hospitality and multi-dwelling unit customers in achieving
energy efficiency goals with smart thermostats and energy management software solutions. Our Electronics and
Controls business unit generated 16% of our net sales and 13% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months
ended March 31, 2024.

**_Product Offerings and Market Segments_**

Within our two business units, we provide products and services across five key market segments, namely
Commercial, Electronics and Control, Industrial, Refrigeration and Residential, throughout the Americas, AMEA
and Europe.

The compressor is the most critical device within the HVACR system, and the most energy-intensive
HVACR component. Each unit is engineered to meet application, segment, and customer requirements to efficiently
separate the evaporator low-pressure side of the system from the condenser high-pressure side. There are six
categories of compressor technology. We invented scroll technology and continue to innovate and scale this
technology platform. Scroll’s flexibility in modulation, superior efficiency and advantages in performance best
positions it to keep up with evolving industry technical requirements and to win share from other technology types.
While scroll is the leading technology for a majority of our served HVACR applications, certain applications are
better suited to other technologies. We have developed a full suite of technology options, including a new offering in
oil-free centrifugal, to meet a wide range of customer technology needs. Our leading portfolio across operating
parameters and served applications creates opportunities for us to leverage global ER&D efforts and to apply
learnings from one segment or region to other segments or regions thus driving productivity and improving our
ability to capture new opportunities in a timely fashion.

In addition to our compression solutions, our Electronics and Controls market segment (to be distinguished
from our Electronic and Controls business unit) generated approximately 19% of our total net sales for the last
twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and approximately 18% for the last three months ended March 31, 2024
(representing a 10% decrease in year over year sales). Our portfolio of “control” products includes perishable and
environmental monitoring solutions, control systems, thermostats, food safety instruments and software solutions.
These products support climate and energy management in residential and commercial buildings, as well as across
the cold chain.

**_Customers and Distribution Channels_**

Our customers include the world’s largest HVAC system OEMs and regional and local HVAC providers,
as well as distributors, wholesalers and end users. Through our market and technology leadership and global
production capacity, we have achieved significant share with leading OEMs who represent approximately one-third
of global sales. Our approximately 800 other customers account for the other two-thirds of global sales. These longtenured OEM relationships provide long-term volume stability, scale and influence. Our highly diversified customer
base helps minimize risks associated with customer concentration.

We tailor our go-to-market strategy across the value chain to best suit specific segments and end customers.
Approximately two-thirds of our products are sold directly to OEMs globally. OEM customers seek advantages in
efficiency, applied cost and compressor performance to reduce design complexity and improve performance. We
also sell our products directly to secondary buyers such as distributors and contractors. Our strong reputation for
product quality and durability, which reduce warranty costs for OEMs and the total long-term cost of ownership for
end customers, has pull-through effects on OEMs and the entire value chain. We further collaborate with channel
influencers, such as researchers, regulators, technical schools and utility providers, to create connectivity with the
entire HVACR ecosystem. In the food retail and food service industries, we work directly with end users as well as
the OEMs to provide solutions, which are sold either to the OEM, through intermediaries or directly to the end user.

We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet required
specifications for each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our
customers, augmenting our strong market position. OEMs launch new product platforms every seven to ten years,
typically in connection with new regulatory standards. These new platforms require significant redesigns that need
many years of product development and close alignment between the OEM and its compressor suppliers. This
dynamic inherently favors our company due to the long-standing, close working relationships between our
engineering teams and our key OEM customers. Between formal launches, platforms are continually modified to
reduce cost and improve efficiency and reliability. The redesign process is less significant and favors the original
compressor supplier on the OEM platform. In addition to our integration in the development cycle, we have built
channels and technical support structures with OEM partners, where they rely on us to provide aftermarket support
and continue to service the installed base. Our role as a trusted partner in customer design and manufacturing
processes has resulted in low customer turnover.

Our technological advantage, deeply integrated partnerships with OEM customers and strong quality
performance together make us indispensable to our customers and support our ability to maintain margins despite
rising input costs. Long-term volume-based agreements (“LTAs”) include mechanisms to pass through material cost
inflation in order to provide stability and resiliency. On average, LTAs are three to four years in length and
approximately one-third of our total net sales are covered by LTAs.

**_Technology Leadership_**

The ongoing cycle of periodic new platform launches and subsequent updates provides us with line of sight
into future customer technology needs, enabling us to tailor our ER&D efforts around anticipated customer
demands. In doing so, we help OEMs keep pace with and shape technology innovations in the HVACR industry. We
have developed a robust and repeatable ER&D process to enable us to be a consistent innovation pioneer. Key
capabilities include: technology discovery and maturation; front-end innovation; world class laboratories and
ecosystems; specialized technical expertise; partnerships with universities, national labs and government agencies;
regulatory agency and industry leadership; and new product development support.

With more than 1,400 engineering and ER&D employees and approximately 500,000 square feet of
engineering labs at 12 major ER&D centers worldwide, including three in Asia and five in Europe, we have
substantial infrastructure to build on our technology leadership. Our ER&D strategy is further supported by the
development of the Helix Innovation Center (the “Helix”), an industry-first space where stakeholders can innovate
at a system or ecosystem level around the industry’s biggest, most complex challenges. The Helix includes six
simulated real-world, fully functional environments allowing us to test and demonstrate our integrated solutions in

-----

total annual sales in the market segments addressable by our current product offerings is approximately $13.4 billion
and such market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of approximately 4% over the next five years.

Demand in our markets is supported by attractive macro drivers such as global regulation shifts, industrydriven sustainability goals and regulatory subsidies and incentives. Based on our current market positioning, our
global scale and flexibility of our supply chain, and our manufacturing and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned to capitalize on these trends.

    - **Regulatory Changes: Regulatory changes have driven change and innovation in our industry for**
decades. However, the frequency and impact of those changes has increased in recent years. These
changes include updates to seasonal energy efficiency ratio (“SEER”) requirements (and other global
efficiency standards) and new standards on refrigerants that drive more frequent compressor and
system innovations. The complexity resulting from these changes favors our global breadth and the
depth of our engineering, technology and operations. In the United States, new efficiency regulations
went into effect January 1, 2023. In 2025, new refrigerant regulations will again drive new
compressors and systems into the market. Additional new regulations in the next seven to ten years are
anticipated. Engineering and development efforts typically begin years in advance of the applicable
regulation effective date. Our OEM customers depend on us to help them meet these requirements in a
timely fashion while simultaneously helping them innovate and differentiate to meet their
sustainability goals. Europe’s sustainability goals and their desire for energy sovereignty is driving
goals and incentives targeting the installation of 30 million new heat pumps by 2030.

    - **Heat Pump Conversion: The growth of heat pumps is expected to bring new customers into the**
HVAC market, as households convert a furnace-only or gas-only system to a heat pump. According to
a major consulting practice, consumers enjoy on average approximately $4,000 in lifetime savings
from heat pumps, supported by government subsidy programs and incentives available from utility
providers. Conversion to heat pumps is expected to be particularly strong in Europe, where high
natural gas prices are incentivizing a transition to less energy-intensive heat pumps. The European
Union (“EU”) is in the process of revising its Energy Performance Building Directive (“EPBD”) to
reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030, a legal obligation under the European climate law,
and make the EU climate-neutral by 2050. While the revision is still under negotiation, the EPBD is
expected to require member states to ensure that all new buildings after 2027 are zero-emission, and
set deadlines after which the use of fossil fuel heating systems in new buildings, or in major building
renovations or renovations of the heating systems, will not be permitted. Existing regulations across
nine European countries have already implemented, or will implement by 2026, fossil fuel boiler bans
in residential buildings. With the upcoming revision of the EPBD, we expect that all other EU member
states will implement similar restrictions and the scope will ultimately comprise all existing buildings.
Some countries also already provide, or are expected to provide, monetary incentives to accelerate the
transition to clean heating, including heat pumps. With strong channel benefits and an existing
customer base, the major legacy boilermakers are playing a critical role in the heat pump transition.
Our HVAC compression expertise positions us as an important partner as legacy boilermakers help to
drive heat pump adoption. Our partnership and existing share with legacy boilermakers and HVAC
OEMs positions us well to enable this transition. We are currently a leader in compression for the heat
pump segment in Europe.

    - **COVID-19 / Hybrid Working: More waking hours spent at home are expected to maintain HVAC**
usage above pre-COVID-19 levels, shortening system useful life. According to a major consulting
practice, these new working arrangements are expected to keep replacement rates elevated as
approximately 45% of employees are predicted to be in hybrid working models in the future versus
approximately 10% pre-COVID-19. HVACR industry executives also expect replacement rates to
remain elevated. Run times in 2020 were quoted as being 30% higher than 2019 levels (after adjusting
for weather), which should correlate to higher rates of replacement over time.

    - **Environmental and Population Shifts: With environmental change resulting in more extreme**
temperatures across the United States, and a population mix increasingly shifting to warmer southern


-----

states, HVAC usage has increased and is expected to continue to increase, resulting in shorter useful
lives for HVAC equipment and higher replacement rates.

**_supply network, and well-positioned for innovation_**

Our deep appreciation of the end user helps us tailor our technology to each customer’s needs, bringing our
global expertise to provide local solutions. This continued technological leadership has helped make us the most
trusted name in compressor solutions. Given our manufacturing presence and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned for the industry’s transition to heat pumps.

Planned and anticipated regulatory changes governing efficiency and refrigerants are expected to provide
stable, ongoing tailwinds to both price and volume. New regulations from the U.S. Department of Energy went into
effect in 2023, with energy efficiency requirements varied by region, and OEM partners are relying on us to design
products that comply with the new regulations. The anticipated transition to low-GWP refrigerants in 2025 will
require considerable engineering, given that compliant refrigerants exhibit different characteristics from existing
refrigerants, such as operating pressures and flammability.

**_Mission critical partner to a diversified global customer base characterized by long-term relationships_**

As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a
small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential
HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the product has a mission-critical impact on function and
efficiency. Compression innovation can create performance, reliability and cost advantages to system design,
therefore enabling value-based selling. Customers will pay a premium for compressors that achieve superior levels
of efficiency, enabling them to reduce other costs within the system design and resulting in an overall lower total
applied system cost.

We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet specifications
required by each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers,
augmenting our industry leadership and helping provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and

opportunities to differentiate. LTAs further support revenue visibility and customer retention. Outside of the United

    - Developing updates to existing platforms in partnership with customers

    - Providing aftermarket products and services to help end-users realize the full useful lives of their
HVACR systems

Deep interconnectivity with our customers’ design and manufacturing processes helps us to provide bestin-class service and support to our customers. This deep integration incentivizes our customers to maintain their
relationships with us. Customer turnover is less than one percent historically. Our technical expertise and operational
support make us a trusted partner.

**_Resilient business model supported by established installed base and high replacement volumes_**

Replacement as a percent of sales has increased to more than 85% over the last 50 years in the North
America residential HVAC industry, with a current installed base of approximately 100 million units. Replacement
sales are more resilient and are associated with durable spend, often outperforming gross domestic product growth
rates during economic cycles. Both HVACR systems broadly and compressors specifically suffer from wear.
Compressors may be replaced to extend the life of an HVACR system. Full system replacement occurs when
HVACR units are beyond repair or when an end-user determines that the payback in higher efficiency, lower
emissions and better reliability is sufficient to warrant the cost of replacement. Repair or replacement of a unit is
non-discretionary because HVACR systems provide essential heating, cooling and refrigeration.

Our resilient recovery during the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis speaks to the largely non-discretionary
nature of HVAC repair and replacement. Despite an approximately 15% revenue contraction in 2009, our revenues
rebounded quickly in 2010 with more than 19% growth before returning to normalized long-term growth rates. Over
the same period, we delivered improvements in gross margin and EBITDA margin as we moved quickly to manage
costs. Our cost structure is largely variable, enabling us to preserve margin during downturns such as the 2007-2008
Global Financial Crisis, the U.S. manufacturing downturn, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

Secular industry tailwinds, including upcoming regulatory changes, heat pump conversion, shifts in
population and the impact of hybrid working, are expected to drive an increase in HVAC usage. This increase in
usage can create more wear on HVAC systems and shorten systems’ useful lives, resulting in increased repair and
replacement rates and driving further demand for replacement products supporting our long-term resilient growth.

**_Proven leadership team with an unmatched breadth of experience_**

Our business is led by a highly qualified and experienced management team. Our management consistently
delivered value to stakeholders while operating as a standalone segment of Emerson. In partnership with Blackstone,
the Copeland team continues to drive innovation and execute on operational excellence in order to capitalize on
strong industry tailwinds.


-----

**_Strong financial profile with best-in-class profitability and free cash flow generation, poised for margin_**
**_expansion through identified efficiency opportunities_**

We have delivered robust and consistent through-the-cycle cash flow performance and top-line growth,
supported by secular industry tailwinds, technology leadership, embedded relationships with customers, and the
mission-critical nature of our product offerings.

**The Transactions**

**_Transaction Agreement_**

On October 30, 2022, the Issuer entered into the Transaction Agreement with Emerson, BCP Emerald and
JV NewCo. The Acquisition was consummated on May 31, 2023, the result of which is (i) JV NewCo holds Climate
Technologies Business, (ii) BCP Emerald acquired approximately 60% of the issued and outstanding common
equity interests of JV NewCo and 100% of the convertible preferred equity interests of JV NewCo, with an initial
liquidation preference of $2.0 billion (the “Convertible PIK Preferred Equity”) and (iii) Emerson retained the
remaining 40% of the issued and outstanding common equity interests of JV NewCo.

Emerson received cash proceeds of approximately $9.5 billion and two senior unsecured notes issued by
EMRLD Seller Notes Issuer L.P., a Delaware limited partnership and a wholly owned subsidiary of JV NewCo (the
“Seller Notes Issuer”) and the direct parent entity of Holdings, in an aggregate principal amount of $2.25 billion (the
“Seller Notes”).

**_Financing Transactions_**

In connection with the closing of the Acquisition, JV NewCo, the Seller Notes Issuer, the Investor Group,
or the Issuer, as the case may be, entered into the following financing transactions (the “Initial Financing
Transactions”):

    - the borrowing by the Issuer of $2,275.0 million under the term loan B facility (the “Original Term
Loan B Facility”) and $450.0 million under the term loan A facility (the “Term Loan A Facility”) and
the Issuer obtaining $700.0 million in commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility (the
“Revolving Credit Facility”);

    - the issuance by the Seller Notes Issuer of $2,250 million aggregate principal amount of two senior
unsecured notes (the “Seller Notes”) to EMR Holdings, Inc., an affiliate of Emerson (“EMR


-----

Holdings”), which are structurally subordinated to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Existing
Notes and will be structurally subordinated to the notes offered hereby;

    - the issuance by JV NewCo of $2,000 million initial liquidation preference of the Convertible PIK
Preferred Equity to the Investor Group;

    - the issuance by the Issuers of $2,275 million aggregate principal amount of dollar notes and
€455 million aggregate principal amount of euro notes; and

    - the investment of $2,521 million in the common equity of JV NewCo by the Investor Group.

**_Term Loan B Facility Refinancing and New Notes Issuance_**

On February 6, 2024, the Company entered into the following refinancing transactions (the “Refinancing
Transactions” and, together with the Initial Financing Transactions, the “Financing Transactions”):

    - the refinancing of the Original Term Loan B Facility and the incurrence of new senior secured term
“B” loans (the “Refinanced Term Loan B Facility”) in an aggregate principal amount of $1,519.3
million; and

    - the issuance by the Issuers of $500.0 million aggregate principal amount of additional dollar notes and
€230 million aggregate principal amount of additional euro notes.

**_Seller Notes Repurchase_**

On June 6, 2024, JV NewCo entered into a Note Purchase Agreement (the “Note Purchase Agreement”)
with Seller Notes Issuer, Emerson and EMR Holdings.

Upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the Note Purchase Agreement, at the closing of the
transactions contemplated by the Note Purchase Agreement (the “Seller Notes Repurchase”), (i) the Seller Notes
Issuer will repurchase the Seller Notes issued by the Seller Notes Issuer to EMR Holdings on May 31, 2023 and (ii)
Emerson will receive cash proceeds of $1.9 billion.

Each party’s obligation to consummate the Seller Notes Repurchase is subject to the satisfaction or waiver
of various customary closing conditions set forth in the Note Purchase Agreement, including (i) the absence of any
law or order that prohibits the consummation of the Seller Notes Repurchase, (ii) obtaining certain regulatory
approvals and (iii) other customary closing conditions and the accuracy of each party’s representations and
warranties and each party’s compliance with its covenants and agreements contained in the Note Purchase
Agreement (subject, in the case of this clause (iii), to certain materiality qualifiers).

The parties to the Note Purchase Agreement have each made customary representations, warranties and
covenants in the Note Purchase Agreement.

The Note Purchase Agreement contains certain other termination rights for the parties thereto, including the
right of each party to terminate the agreement if the Seller Notes Repurchase has not been consummated by
December 31, 2024 (the “Outside Date”).

The Seller Notes Issuer expects to finance the Seller Notes Repurchase with the net proceeds of this
offering, borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility and cash on hand.

**_Unit Purchase Transaction_**

On June 6, 2024, BCP Emerald entered into a Unit Purchase Agreement (the “Unit Purchase Agreement”
and, together with the Note Purchase Agreement, the “Purchase Agreements”) with JV NewCo, Emerald JV


-----

Holdings G.P. LLC, a Delaware limited liability company and the general partner of JV NewCo and certain whollyowned subsidiaries of Emerson (the “Unit Sellers”).

Upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the Unit Purchase Agreement, at the closing of the
transactions contemplated by the Unit Purchase Agreement (the “Unit Purchase Transaction”), (i) BCP Emerald will
acquire approximately 40% common equity interest of JV NewCo held by Emerson through the Unit Sellers,
reducing Emerson’s equity interest in JV NewCo to zero and (ii) Emerson will receive cash proceeds of $1.5 billion.

BCP Emerald expects to finance the Unit Purchase Transaction with the issuance of new equity from the
Sponsors and certain co-investors.

The closings of the Unit Purchase Transaction and the Seller Notes Repurchase are not required to occur
simultaneously. Additionally, this offering is not conditioned upon the closing of the transactions contemplated by
the Purchase Agreements.

**Escrow**

If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneously with this offering, concurrently with the
closing of this offering, the Issuers will enter into an escrow agreement relating to the notes (the “Escrow
Agreement”) with U.S. Bank Trust Company, National Association, as trustee for the notes and U.S. Bank National
Association and/or another nationally recognized financial institution chosen by the Issuer in its reasonable
discretion (in such capacity, the “Escrow Agent”), pursuant to which the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be
deposited) an amount equal to the gross proceeds of the notes offered hereby into an escrow account for the notes
until the conditions to release of the property in the escrow account (the “Escrow Release Conditions”) are satisfied.
If, among other things, the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, the Issuer
will redeem, on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined below) in accordance with the terms of the
indenture that will govern the notes, all of the notes at the Special Mandatory Redemption Price (the “Special
Mandatory Redemption”).
