**Critical Accounting Policies**

Preparation of the Company’s financial statements requires management to make judgments, assumptions
and estimates regarding uncertainties that could affect reported revenue, expenses, assets, liabilities and equity. The
most significant areas where management judgments and estimates impact the financial statements are described
below. Actual results in these areas could differ materially from management’s estimates under different
assumptions or conditions. This discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with our consolidated
financial statements and related notes.

For the Predecessor periods, the Company’s financial statements were prepared on a stand-alone basis
derived from the consolidated financial statements and accounting records of Emerson. The financial statements for
the Predecessor periods are presented as carve-out financial statements and reflect the combined historical results of
operations, financial position and cash flows of Climate Technologies, as if such financial statements were
historically managed this way, in conformity with GAAP.

**_Business Combination_**

The Company accounts for business combinations under the acquisition method of accounting. This
method requires the recording of acquired assets, including separately identifiable intangible assets, at their
acquisition date fair values. Any excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair value of the identifiable net
assets acquired is recorded as goodwill. The determination of the estimated fair value of assets acquired requires
management’s judgment and often involves the use of significant estimates and assumptions, including assumptions
with respect to the weighted average cost of capital, discount rate, prospective financial information including
revenue growth rate, EBITDA margin, customer attrition rates, royalty rates, obsolescence factors, asset lives and
market multiples, among other items. When necessary, the Company consults with external advisors to help
determine fair value. For non-observable market values, the Company may determine fair value using acceptable


-----

valuation principles, including the excess earnings, relief from royalty, lost profit or cost methods. Management’s
estimates of fair value are based upon assumptions believed to be reasonable, but which are inherently uncertain and
unpredictable, and as a result, actual results may differ from estimates. In addition, unanticipated events and
circumstances may occur that may affect the accuracy or validity of such estimates.

During the measurement period, which is one year from the acquisition date, the Company may record
adjustments to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed with the corresponding offset to goodwill. Upon
conclusion of the measurement period, any subsequent adjustments are recorded to earnings.

**_Revenue Recognition_**

In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 606, Revenue from Contracts with
_Customers, the Company evaluates its contracts with customers to identify the promised goods or services and_
recognize revenue for the identified performance obligations at the amount the Company expects to be entitled to in
exchange for those goods or services. A performance obligation is a promise in a contract to transfer a distinct good
or service to a customer. Revenue is recognized when, or as performance obligations are satisfied, and control has
transferred to the customer, typically when products are shipped or delivered, title and risk of loss pass to the
customer, and the Company has a present right to payment.

The vast majority of the Company’s revenues are performance obligations related to the sale of
manufactured products which are recognized at a point in time when control transfers in accordance with shipping
terms. In limited circumstances, contracts include multiple performance obligations, where revenue is recognized
separately for each good or service, as well as contracts where revenue is recognized over time as control transfers
to the customer.

For revenues recognized over time, the Company typically uses an input method to determine progress and
recognize revenue, based on costs incurred. The Company believes costs incurred closely correspond with its
performance under the contract and the transfer of control to the customer.

In sales arrangements that involve multiple performance obligations, revenue is allocated based on the
relative standalone selling price for each performance obligation. Observable selling prices from actual transactions
are used whenever possible. In other instances, the Company determines the standalone selling price based on thirdparty pricing or management’s best estimate.

Payment terms vary but are generally short-term in nature. The Company’s long-term contracts, where
revenue is generally recognized over time, are billed as work progresses in accordance with the contract terms and
conditions, either at periodic intervals or upon achievement of certain milestones. The timing of revenue recognition
and billings under these contracts results in either unbilled receivables (contract assets) when revenue recognized
exceeds billings, or customer advances (contract liabilities) when billings exceed revenue recognized. Unbilled
receivables are reclassified to accounts receivable when an unconditional right to consideration exists, typically
when a milestone in the contract is achieved. The Company does not evaluate whether the transaction price includes
a significant financing component for contracts where the time between cash collection and performance is less than
one year.

Certain arrangements with customers include variable consideration, typically in the form of rebates, cash
discounts or penalties. Other than standard product warranty provisions, sales arrangements provide no other post
shipment obligations on the Company. In most instances, returns are limited to product quality issues. The Company
records a reduction to revenue at the time of sale to reflect the ultimate amount of consideration it expects to receive.
The Company’s estimates are updated quarterly based on historical experience, trend analysis, and expected market
conditions. Variable consideration is typically not constrained at the time revenue is recognized.

The Company records amounts billed to customers for the costs of shipping and handling in sales
transactions as Revenue and such costs are not considered separate performance obligations.


-----

**_Goodwill and Other Intangibles Impairment Testing_**

The Company amortizes definite-lived intangible assets on a straight-line basis over their useful lives.
Goodwill is not amortized and is required to be assessed at least annually for impairment, or more frequently if
triggering events indicate a possible impairment. The Company continually evaluates financial performance,
economic conditions and other recent developments in assessing if a triggering event indicates that the carrying
value of goodwill is impaired. Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level by first performing a
qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less
than its carrying value. If the reporting unit does not pass the qualitative assessment, then a quantitative assessment
is performed to compare the reporting unit’s carrying value to its fair value. Estimated fair values are developed
primarily under an income approach that discounts estimated future cash flows using risk adjusted interest rates, as
well as earnings multiples or other techniques as warranted. Fair values are subject to changes in underlying
economic conditions. Alternatively, we are permitted to bypass the qualitative assessment and proceed directly to
performing the quantitative assessment. Goodwill is considered impaired if the carrying value of the reporting unit
exceeds its fair value. The fair value of the reporting unit is based on a discounted cash flow model involving several
assumptions.

Identifiable intangible assets consist of intellectual property, trade names, developed technology, backlog,
and customer relationships and are also subject to evaluation for potential impairment if events or circumstances
indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.

No goodwill or intangible asset impairment was recorded for any of the periods presented.

**_Stock-based Compensation_**

The Company measures equity-classified stock-based compensation awards at their grant date fair value,
whereas liability-classified awards are remeasured to fair value at each reporting period. Expense for stock-based
compensation awards is recognized over the requisite service period and forfeitures are accounted for as they occur.

**_Inventories_**

Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value and are valued based on standard costs
which approximate average costs. Cost standards are revised at the beginning of each fiscal year. The annual effect
of resetting standards plus operating variances incurred during each period are allocated between inventories and
recognized in cost of sales as products are sold.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

In the normal course of business, the Company is exposed to changes in foreign currency exchange rates
and commodity prices. The Company’s foreign currency exposures relate to transactions denominated in currencies
that differ from the functional currencies of its subsidiaries, principally Mexican pesos. Foreign exchange forwards
are utilized, as needed, to hedge foreign currency exposures impacting sales or cost of sales transactions, firm
commitments, or the fair value of assets and liabilities. Based on a hypothetical 10.0% weakening in the U.S. dollar
across all currencies, the potential losses in future earnings, fair value or cash flows are not material.


-----

**_Commodities_**

Commodity exposures are price fluctuations on forecasted purchases of copper and aluminum. All
derivatives are associated with specific underlying exposures and the Company does not hold derivatives for trading
or speculative purposes. The initial duration of hedge positions is less than two years. Based on a hypothetical 10%
decrease in commodity prices or a 10.0% weakening in the U.S. dollar across all currencies, the potential losses in
future earnings, fair value or cash flows are not material.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

As of March 31, 2024, we have approximately $5,438.7 million of total third-party indebtedness
outstanding, including $1,965.5 million of borrowings at variable interest rates under our Term Loan Facilities. A
0.25% increase in the rate of interest under our Term Loan Facilities would increase our annual interest expense by
approximately $7.2 million. This amount would increase to the extent any additional variable interest rate
borrowings are made on our Revolving Credit Facility.

**BUSINESS**

**Our Company**

We are a leading global manufacturer of mission critical compressors, controls, components and solutions
to the HVACR market. We provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and
safety, advance energy efficiency, and create environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Key components in an
HVACR ecosystem include the compressor, controls, the condenser and the evaporator. We provide best-in-class
compressors, controls, components and solutions for residential, commercial, industrial and transportation
applications. We are the largest global manufacturer in our served markets with approximately 40% share in overall
global compression, including approximately 70% in the North America residential HVAC segment, and strong
positions within our non-compression offerings.

Our large installed base of more than 150 million HVAC compressor units globally drives profitable
aftermarket sales due to replacement dynamics, with approximately 80% of our net sales tied to repair or
replacement activity. Ongoing technology leadership is a key driver of our ability to capitalize on the replacement
cycle, as each successive generation of compressor provides greater cost savings, energy efficiency and higher levels
of environmental sustainability impact.

The replacement cycle is primarily driven by repair and replacement of HVACR systems. Our installed
base provides a foundation for ongoing earnings resilience as systems age and require repair or replacement. Global
regulations around the impact of refrigerants on global warming and the need for energy efficiency amplify
replacement dynamics in our business. Globally, government programs and incentives support the adoption of new,
more sustainable products creating a strong forward looking growth environment. Secular trends tied to human
health and comfort, as well as food quality, safety and sustainability drive additional demand for our compression
and solutions offerings.

As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a
small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential
HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the compressor has a mission-critical impact on function and
efficiency. Compressors enable the separation of the low-pressure side of an HVAC system, where heat is absorbed
into the refrigerant, from the high-pressure side of the system, where heat is discharged from the refrigerant to a
cooling medium (typically the ambient outside air). The compressor mechanically reduces the volume of low-side
refrigerant, thereby increasing its pressure and enabling heated refrigerant to flow to the high-pressure side of the
system, where it is cooled.


-----

We offer a variety of compressor technologies to meet customer-specific applications. Compression
technology is essential to improving system efficiency. In addition, refrigerant selection is dependent on rigorous
testing by compressor manufacturers to evaluate for performance and reliability and approve for use. Globally, the
HVACR system manufacturers are dependent upon compressor innovation to meet regulations for efficiency and
more environmentally friendly refrigerants. Because compressors are highly engineered to meet our customers’
technical requirements, we work closely with them on ER&D efforts to develop technology that meets consumer
needs and complies with regulatory changes. These tightly coupled relationships result from our industry leadership
and help provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and opportunities to differentiate
ourselves.

**Environmental Sustainability**

We believe compressors lie at the nexus of energy efficiency, helping build environmental sustainability
and playing a role in ESG-related trends. Environmental sustainability is inherently embedded in what we do, as we
enable our customers to set environmental sustainability goals and consistently meet or exceed ever-increasing
sustainability standards. The best compressors—the most energy efficient, the quietest, the most reliable—are also
the most environmentally sustainable and the most cost efficient for our OEM customers and the end users of their
products. Consistently improving energy efficiency and sustainability requires continued technological innovation
which is made possible by our extensive and proven ER&D capabilities.

**_Business Unit Overview_**

Our business is organized into two broad categories (HVACR Technologies and Electronics and Controls),
with three world areas included within the HVACR Technologies group (HVACR Americas, HVACR AMEA
(Asia, Middle-East and Africa) and HVACR Europe).

Further, for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA of $4,722.7 million and $1,361.0 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Consolidated and
Combined Financial Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to net earnings, the closest
comparable GAAP measure.

**_HVACR Technologies_**

The businesses within our HVACR Technologies group are leading producers of compression and related
controls and solutions for residential, commercial, refrigeration, industrial, and transport markets. Our pioneering
leadership of the scroll type of compressor enables foundational leadership across a majority of our served markets.
To meet the diverse needs of other compressor applications, we also provide hermetic, semi-hermetic, centrifugal,
screw and reciprocating compressors. The depth and breadth of our portfolio is unmatched globally, allowing us to
steward market change and innovation across a wide range of market segments and applications. Our global
HVACR Technologies group generated 84% of our total net sales and 87% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last
twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

**HVACR Americas is our largest business unit and operates within an environment where our scroll**
technology is extremely well-suited for applications across the served market. This business unit generated 57% of
our total net sales and 59% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our leading
positions with the largest North American OEMs serving the residential, commercial and transportation segments is
augmented by our leadership with a more fragmented set of refrigeration and industrial customers. Above and
beyond the growth that an accelerated energy efficiency and low GWP refrigerant regulatory environment is driving
for our core residential, commercial and refrigeration markets, our industrial business is well-positioned for
sustainability-driven growth within the RNG segment. The industrial business is roughly divided 50/50 between
traditional industrial refrigeration applications and RNG applications. The RNG space is growing at a double-digit
compound annual growth rate the past few years and growth is expected to accelerate given sustainability trends and
the associated policies and incentives to deal with landfill and other off-gassing, largely farm-digestor applications.
We are well-positioned with key customers in this space, as well as with their solution providers and engineering
contractors. Broad heating, cooling and refrigeration needs across the Americas region coupled with a mature
regulatory environment provide a solid foundation for continued growth and innovation opportunities.

Our leadership in HVACR AMEA is driven by balanced sales between residential, commercial and
refrigeration applications. Our technology leadership in commercial, district and other heating and refrigeration
segments in China is complemented by our broad leadership positions in the rest of the region, including high
ambient temperature and residential applications in countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. HVACR AMEA
generated 18% of our net sales and 22% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

**HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest**
growing business unit as fossil-fueled boiler systems are being replaced by heat pump and dual fuel solutions,
applications where we are a leading compressor and solutions provider. HVACR Europe generated 9% of our net
sales and 6% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

**_Electronics and Controls_**

Our Electronics and Controls business unit is a global leader in cold chain controls, monitoring solutions
and climate control products and solutions. We provide building and refrigeration controls and monitoring solutions
for food retail and foodservice applications, refrigerated container and perishable cargo monitoring solutions for


-----

cargo and marine applications and healthcare environmental safety monitoring solutions. Our business benefits from
sustainability, energy management and digitalization tailwinds, including integrated refrigeration solutions across
compressors and controls, market penetration opportunities with leading automation capabilities, expanding data
services and analytics in cargo monitoring, and healthcare monitoring and grid-connected energy management
solutions. We also provide traditional and connected thermostats, energy and building management solutions, gas
valves, cooling controls and control electronics. Our business benefits from energy efficiency, connectivity and
control tailwinds, including opportunities to support hospitality and multi-dwelling unit customers in achieving
energy efficiency goals with smart thermostats and energy management software solutions. Our Electronics and
Controls business unit generated 16% of our net sales and 13% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months
ended March 31, 2024.

**_Product Offerings and Market Segments_**

Within our two business units, we provide products and services across five key market segments, namely
Commercial, Electronics and Control, Industrial, Refrigeration and Residential, throughout the Americas, AMEA
and Europe.

Across the Copeland brand, as well as the Sensi, Verdant, Vilter and White-Rodgers sub-brands, we
provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy

-----

Comprising approximately 81% of our total net sales for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our
HVACR market segments, including residential and commercial HVAC compression, refrigeration and related
aftermarket, and industrial, play an important role for our business (approximately 36% residential HVAC
compression, approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression, approximately 22% refrigeration and related
aftermarket, and approximately 4% industrial). In addition, for the three months ended March 31, 2024,
approximately 82% of our total net sales were generated from our HVACR compression market segment, consisting
of approximately 34% residential HVAC compression (representing a 15% decrease in year over year sales),
approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression (representing a 1% increase in year over year sales),
approximately 23% refrigeration and related aftermarket (representing a 5% increase in year over year sales), and
approximately 5% industrial (representing a 39% increase in year over year sales).

The compressor is the most critical device within the HVACR system, and the most energy-intensive
HVACR component. Each unit is engineered to meet application, segment, and customer requirements to efficiently
separate the evaporator low-pressure side of the system from the condenser high-pressure side. There are six
categories of compressor technology. We invented scroll technology and continue to innovate and scale this
technology platform. Scroll’s flexibility in modulation, superior efficiency and advantages in performance best
positions it to keep up with evolving industry technical requirements and to win share from other technology types.
While scroll is the leading technology for a majority of our served HVACR applications, certain applications are
better suited to other technologies. We have developed a full suite of technology options, including a new offering in
oil-free centrifugal, to meet a wide range of customer technology needs. Our leading portfolio across operating
parameters and served applications creates opportunities for us to leverage global ER&D efforts and to apply
learnings from one segment or region to other segments or regions thus driving productivity and improving our
ability to capture new opportunities in a timely fashion.

In addition to our compression solutions, our Electronics and Controls market segment (to be distinguished
from our Electronic and Controls business unit) generated approximately 19% of our total net sales for the last
twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and approximately 18% for the last three months ended March 31, 2024
(representing a 10% decrease in year over year sales). Our portfolio of “control” products includes perishable and
environmental monitoring solutions, control systems, thermostats, food safety instruments and software solutions.
These products support climate and energy management in residential and commercial buildings, as well as across
the cold chain.

**_Customers and Distribution Channels_**

Our customers include the world’s largest HVAC system OEMs and regional and local HVAC providers,
as well as distributors, wholesalers and end users. Through our market and technology leadership and global
production capacity, we have achieved significant share with leading OEMs who represent approximately one-third
of global sales. Our approximately 800 other customers account for the other two-thirds of global sales. These longtenured OEM relationships provide long-term volume stability, scale and influence. Our highly diversified customer
base helps minimize risks associated with customer concentration.

We tailor our go-to-market strategy across the value chain to best suit specific segments and end customers.
Approximately two-thirds of our products are sold directly to OEMs globally. OEM customers seek advantages in
efficiency, applied cost and compressor performance to reduce design complexity and improve performance. We
also sell our products directly to secondary buyers such as distributors and contractors. Our strong reputation for
product quality and durability, which reduce warranty costs for OEMs and the total long-term cost of ownership for
end customers, has pull-through effects on OEMs and the entire value chain. We further collaborate with channel
influencers, such as researchers, regulators, technical schools and utility providers, to create connectivity with the
entire HVACR ecosystem. In the food retail and food service industries, we work directly with end users as well as
the OEMs to provide solutions, which are sold either to the OEM, through intermediaries or directly to the end user.

We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet required
specifications for each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our
customers, augmenting our strong market position. OEMs launch new product platforms every seven to ten years,
typically in connection with new regulatory standards. These new platforms require significant redesigns that need


-----

many years of product development and close alignment between the OEM and its compressor suppliers. This
dynamic inherently favors our company due to the long-standing, close working relationships between our
engineering teams and our key OEM customers. Between formal launches, platforms are continually modified to
reduce cost and improve efficiency and reliability. The redesign process is less significant and favors the original
compressor supplier on the OEM platform. In addition to our integration in the development cycle, we have built
channels and technical support structures with OEM partners, where they rely on us to provide aftermarket support
and continue to service the installed base. Our role as a trusted partner in customer design and manufacturing
processes has resulted in low customer turnover.

Our technological advantage, deeply integrated partnerships with OEM customers and strong quality
performance together make us indispensable to our customers and support our ability to maintain margins despite
rising input costs. LTAs include mechanisms to pass through material cost inflation in order to provide stability and
resiliency. On average, LTAs are three to four years in length and approximately one-third of our total net sales are
covered by LTAs.

**_Technology Leadership_**

The ongoing cycle of periodic new platform launches and subsequent updates provides us with line of sight
into future customer technology needs, enabling us to tailor our ER&D efforts around anticipated customer
demands. In doing so, we help OEMs keep pace with and shape technology innovations in the HVACR industry. We
have developed a robust and repeatable ER&D process to enable us to be a consistent innovation pioneer. Key
capabilities include: technology discovery and maturation; front-end innovation; world class laboratories and
ecosystems; specialized technical expertise; partnerships with universities, national labs and government agencies;
regulatory agency and industry leadership; and new product development support.

With more than 1,400 engineering and ER&D employees and approximately 500,000 square feet of
engineering labs at 12 major ER&D centers worldwide, including three in Asia and five in Europe, we have
substantial infrastructure to build on our technology leadership. Our ER&D strategy is further supported by the
development of the Helix, an industry-first space where stakeholders can innovate at a system or ecosystem level
around the industry’s biggest, most complex challenges. The Helix includes six simulated real-world, fully
functional environments allowing us to test and demonstrate our integrated solutions in real-world environments.
The Helix positions our company as a key thought leader and solutions provider in the HVACR industry.

**_Geographic and Manufacturing Footprint_**

We serve our customers through 27 global manufacturing facilities and 12 major global ER&D centers,
with a global headcount of approximately 18,000 employees. Global scale paired with localized manufacturing
enable us to think globally and act locally, creating a flexible and robust supply chain that is regionalized to provide
customers with a strong on-time delivery record. This advantage is derived not just from global operations, but also
from the breadth of our product offerings and our ability to meet customers’ requirements. Decades of research and
customer collaboration have ultimately yielded an unmatched global HVAC installed base of more than 150 million
units.

Our HVACR business is geographically focused in the Americas, where we generate approximately 70% of
total net sales, with AMEA and Europe generating approximately 20% and 11% of total net sales, respectively. As
the European business continues to grow at a pace faster than other regions due to heat pump and other application
opportunities, we will benefit from further diversification and greater global presence. Traditional European
compressor manufacturers do not have meaningful presence in residential applications, thus favoring our
competitive position as we help build out a heat pump infrastructure to replace fossil-fuel burning boiler systems.

Our continued global expansion into new regions with attractive market dynamics remains a priority and
will be actively supported by our existing global infrastructure and network.


-----

**Our Industry**

We participate in the HVACR compression and related solutions and controls markets with a focus on
residential, commercial, refrigeration, transportation, industrial and cold chain applications. We estimate that the
total annual sales in the market segments addressable by our current product offerings is approximately $13.4 billion
and such market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of approximately 4% over the next five years.

Demand in our markets is supported by attractive macro drivers such as global regulation shifts, industrydriven sustainability goals and regulatory subsidies and incentives. Based on our current market positioning, our
global scale and flexibility of our supply chain, and our manufacturing and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned to capitalize on these trends.

    - **Regulatory Changes: Regulatory changes have driven change and innovation in our industry for**
decades. However, the frequency and impact of those changes has increased in recent years. These
changes include updates to SEER requirements (and other global efficiency standards) and new
standards on refrigerants that drive more frequent compressor and system innovations. The complexity
resulting from these changes favors our global breadth and the depth of our engineering, technology
and operations. In the United States, new efficiency regulations went into effect January 1, 2023. In
2025, new refrigerant regulations will again drive new compressors and systems into the market.
Additional new regulations in the next seven to ten years are anticipated. Engineering and development
efforts typically begin years in advance of the applicable regulation effective date. Our OEM
customers depend on us to help them meet these requirements in a timely fashion while simultaneously
helping them innovate and differentiate to meet their sustainability goals. Europe’s sustainability goals
and their desire for energy sovereignty is driving goals and incentives targeting the installation of
30 million new heat pumps by 2030.

    - **Heat Pump Conversion: The growth of heat pumps is expected to bring new customers into the**
HVAC market, as households convert a furnace-only or gas-only system to a heat pump. According to
a major consulting practice, consumers enjoy on average approximately $4,000 in lifetime savings


-----

from heat pumps, supported by government subsidy programs and incentives available from utility
providers.

    - Conversion to heat pumps is expected to be particularly strong in Europe, where high natural gas
prices are incentivizing a transition to less energy-intensive heat pumps. The EU is in the process of
revising its EPBD to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030, a legal obligation under the
European climate law, and make the EU climate-neutral by 2050. While the revision is still under
negotiation, the EPBD is expected to require member states to ensure that all new buildings after 2027
are zero-emission, and set deadlines after which the use of fossil fuel heating systems in new buildings,
or in major building renovations or renovations of the heating systems, will not be permitted. Existing
regulations across nine European countries have already implemented, or will implement by 2026,
fossil fuel boiler bans in residential buildings. With the upcoming revision of the EPBD, we expect that
all other EU member states will implement similar restrictions and the scope will ultimately comprise
all existing buildings. Some countries also already provide, or are expected to provide, monetary
incentives to accelerate the transition to clean heating, including heat pumps. With strong channel
benefits and an existing customer base, the major legacy boilermakers are playing a critical role in the
heat pump transition. Our HVAC compression expertise positions us as an important partner as legacy
boilermakers help drive heat pump adoption. Our partnership and existing share with legacy
boilermakers and HVAC OEMs positions us well to enable this transition. We are currently a leader in
compression for the heat pump segment in Europe.

    - **COVID-19 / Hybrid Working: More waking hours spent at home are expected to maintain HVAC**
usage above pre-COVID-19 levels, shortening system useful life. According to a major consulting
practice, these new working arrangements are expected to keep replacement rates elevated as
approximately 45% of employees are predicted to be in hybrid working models in the future versus
approximately 10% pre-COVID-19. HVACR industry executives also expect replacement rates to
remain elevated. Run times in 2020 were quoted as being 30% higher than 2019 levels (after adjusting
for weather), which should correlate to higher rates of replacement over time.

    - **Environmental and Population Shifts: With environmental change resulting in more extreme**
temperatures across the United States, and a population mix increasingly shifting to warmer southern
states, HVAC usage has increased and is expected to continue to increase, resulting in shorter useful
lives for HVAC equipment and higher replacement rates.

**Our Key Strengths**

**_Established global leader with clear #1 market position_**

We are the #1 manufacturer of HVACR compression products in the segments and regions where we
compete, driven by technology leadership, strong brand recognition, global facilities footprint and long-term
customer relationships. We are the clear leader in terms of global scale and presence, as well as breadth and quality
of our product portfolio, and we compete against different peers in each segment and region where we operate. Our
size and scale enable operational synergies driven by our ability to leverage technology, ER&D and manufacturing
excellence across regions.

**_Unrivaled breadth and depth of product portfolio and capabilities executed through a global ER&D_**
**_supply network, and well-positioned for innovation_**

Our global manufacturing capabilities, paired with our leading portfolio of SKUs and patents, enable us to
provide what our customers need, where they need it, and when they need it. No competitor can match our global
reach across markets and segments. Our leading technology position is supported by more than 3,000 patents and
pending applications. Extensive ER&D capabilities in the United States and Asia, along with a growing ER&D
functionality in Europe, enable us to offer truly global ER&D capabilities to meet the needs of each individual
customer and application.


-----

These capabilities, combined with our deeply integrated relationships with leading OEMs and decades of
experience have made us an industry leader in technological advancement. We work collaboratively with regulators
to understand future efficiency capability standards and we are developing the solutions to meet those standards with
the world’s leading HVACR manufacturers. Leveraging these partnerships and our global ER&D infrastructure, we
are able to take a leadership position in shaping each wave of regulatory transition.

Our deep appreciation of the end user helps us tailor our technology to each customer’s needs, bringing our
global expertise to provide local solutions. This continued technological leadership has helped make us the most
trusted name in compressor solutions. Given our manufacturing presence and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned for the industry’s transition to heat pumps.

Planned and anticipated regulatory changes governing efficiency and refrigerants are expected to provide
stable, ongoing tailwinds to both price and volume. New regulations from the U.S. Department of Energy went into
effect in 2023, with energy efficiency requirements varied by region, and OEM partners are relying on us to design
products that comply with the new regulations. The anticipated transition to low-GWP refrigerants in 2025 will
require considerable engineering, given that compliant refrigerants exhibit different characteristics from existing
refrigerants, such as operating pressures and flammability.

**_Mission critical partner to a diversified global customer base characterized by long-term relationships_**

As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a
small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential
HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the product has a mission-critical impact on function and
efficiency. Compression innovation can create performance, reliability and cost advantages to system design,
therefore enabling value-based selling. Customers will pay a premium for compressors that achieve superior levels
of efficiency, enabling them to reduce other costs within the system design and resulting in an overall lower total
applied system cost.

We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet specifications
required by each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers,
augmenting our industry leadership and helping provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and
opportunities to differentiate. LTAs further support revenue visibility and customer retention. Outside of the United
States, where the customer base is more diversified and fragmented, LTAs are utilized less frequently.

**_Highly engineered offering promotes customer retention through customer process integration_**

In addition to the critical nature of compressors within HVAC systems, we also serve as a critical
engineering, development, and manufacturing partner to our customers. We provide crucial services to our
customers at every stage of the product lifecycle by:

    - Helping customers develop specifications to meet new regulatory requirements

    - Innovating compressor technology to meet the requirements

    - Manufacturing units at scale and on time to support new platform launches

    - Developing updates to existing platforms in partnership with customers

    - Providing aftermarket products and services to help end-users realize the full useful lives of their
HVACR systems

Deep interconnectivity with our customers’ design and manufacturing processes helps us to provide bestin-class service and support to our customers. This deep integration incentivizes our customers to maintain their
relationships with us. Customer turnover is less than one percent historically. Our technical expertise and operational
support make us a trusted partner.


-----

**_Resilient business model supported by established installed base and high replacement volumes_**

Replacement as a percent of sales has increased to more than 85% over the last 50 years in the North
America residential HVAC industry, with a current installed base of approximately 100 million units. Replacement
sales are more resilient and are associated with durable spend, often outperforming GDP growth rates during
economic cycles. Both HVACR systems broadly and compressors specifically suffer from wear. Compressors may
be replaced to extend the life of an HVACR system. Full system replacement occurs when HVACR units are beyond
repair or when an end-user determines that the payback in higher efficiency, lower emissions and better reliability is
sufficient to warrant the cost of replacement. Repair or replacement of a unit is non-discretionary because HVACR
systems provide essential heating, cooling and refrigeration.

Our resilient recovery during the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis speaks to the largely non-discretionary
nature of HVAC repair and replacement. Despite an approximately 15% revenue contraction in 2009, our revenues
rebounded quickly in 2010 with more than 19% growth before returning to normalized long-term growth rates. Over
the same period, we delivered improvements in gross margin and EBITDA margin as we moved quickly to manage
costs. Our cost structure is largely variable, enabling us to preserve margin during downturns such as the 2007-2008
Global Financial Crisis, the U.S. manufacturing downturn, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

Secular industry tailwinds, including upcoming regulatory changes, heat pump conversion, shifts in
population and the impact of hybrid working, are expected to drive an increase in HVAC usage. This increase in
usage can create more wear on HVAC systems and shorten systems’ useful lives, resulting in increased repair and
replacement rates and driving further demand for replacement products supporting our long-term resilient growth.

**_Proven leadership team with an unmatched breadth of experience_**

Our business is led by a highly qualified and experienced management team. Our management consistently
delivered value to stakeholders while operating as a standalone segment of Emerson. In partnership with Blackstone,
the Copeland team continues to drive innovation and execute on operational excellence in order to capitalize on
strong industry tailwinds.

**_Strong financial profile with best-in-class profitability and free cash flow generation, poised for margin_**
**_expansion through identified efficiency opportunities_**

We have delivered robust and consistent through-the-cycle cash flow performance and top-line growth,
supported by secular industry tailwinds, technology leadership, embedded relationships with customers, and the
mission-critical nature of our product offerings.

**Competition**

We operate in highly competitive markets. We compete based on product performance, quality, delivery,
branding, service, total applied cost and/or price across the industries and markets served. A significant element of
our competitive strategy is to deliver solutions to our customers by manufacturing high-quality products at the best
applied cost. Although no single company competes directly with us in all of our product lines, various companies
compete in one or more product lines with the number of competitors varying by product line. Some competitors
have substantially greater sales, assets and financial resources than our business and we also compete with many
smaller companies. We believe we have a market leadership position in many of our product lines.

**Intellectual Property**

We maintain an intellectual property portfolio we have developed or acquired over a number of years,
including patents, trademarks and licenses. We also continue to develop or acquire new intellectual property. New
patent applications are continuously filed to protect our ongoing research and development activities and we
periodically review the continued utility of patent assets. Our trademark registrations may be renewed and their
duration is dependent upon national laws and trademark use. While this proprietary intellectual property portfolio is
important to our business in the aggregate, we do not regard our business as being dependent on any single patent,
trademark registration or license.

We believe that we have taken all necessary steps to protect our intellectual property rights, but no
assurance can be given that we will be able to successfully enforce or protect our rights in the event that they are
infringed upon by a third-party.

**Government Regulation**

We are subject to a number of U.S. federal and state and foreign laws and regulations that affect
manufacturing companies. Many of these laws and regulations are still evolving and being tested in courts. These
involve HVACR efficiency and refrigeration requirements, the environment, labor and employment, health and
safety, intellectual property, data privacy and security, advertising, marketing, competition, consumer protection,
taxation, economic or other trade prohibitions or sanctions and securities law compliance.

_Environmental Regulation_

Our operations, products and services are subject to various environmental laws and regulations, including
obligations to obtain and comply with permits required for the operation of our business and to meet applicable
safety or stewardship standards. Our manufacturing locations generate wastes (including hazardous wastes), of
which use, handling, storage, treatment, transportation, discharge and disposal are subject to U.S. federal, state,
foreign and/or local laws and regulations relating to pollution, public and worker health and safety and protection of
the environment. We strive to minimize the environmental impact of our operations through pollution control
technologies, facility design and operating procedures. Compliance with environmental laws and regulations has not
had, and based on currently available information and the applicable laws and regulations currently in effect, is not
expected to have a material effect on our capital expenditures (including expenditures for pollution control
equipment), earnings or competitive position. However, environmental requirements have and are expected to
continue to become increasingly stringent, and environmental laws and regulations may be changed, accelerated or
adopted that impose significant operational restrictions and compliance requirements upon us and which could
negatively impact our operating results.

In addition, we are also subject to obligations under federal and state environmental laws to complete
investigations and remediation at several of our current and former operating locations as well as having been
assessed a share of responsibility for remedial activities at certain third-party disposal (i.e., “Superfund”) sites.
Based on our information regarding the nature and volume of wastes allegedly disposed of or released at these
properties, the total estimated cleanup costs and other financially viable potentially responsible parties, we do not
believe the costs to us associated with these properties will be material, either individually or in the aggregate. As of


-----

September 30, 2023, financial reserves of $16.6 million have been established for the reasonably estimable costs of
such matters.

_Employee Health and Safety Regulations_

We are subject to requirements relating to safe working conditions and manufacturing practices, including
in the United States federal and state Occupational Safety and Health (OSHA) standards and regulations. Employee
health and safety in the workplace is one of our core values. The Climate Technologies leadership team will
continue to support our employees with training, policies and other resources to provide a safe and healthy
workplace. Hazards in the workplace are actively identified, and incident tracking is implemented, so that
preventative and remedial actions can be taken to maintain and improve workplace safety.

**Employees and Human Capital**

We are dedicated to modernizing our workplace culture with the goal of meeting the needs and
expectations of today’s workers and attract talent that will help us thrive. We believe our success depends on our
ability to attract, develop and retain key personnel. The skills, experience and industry knowledge of key employees
significantly benefit our operations and performance. We develop our employees and future leaders internally with
programs that focus on business development, managerial skills, inclusion and employee engagement.

We support and develop our employees through global training and development programs that build and
strengthen employees’ leadership and professional skills. Leadership development programs include intensive
learning programs for new leaders as well as more established leaders. We also partner with educational institutions
and nonprofit organizations to help prepare current and future workers with knowledge and skills to succeed. To
assess and improve employee retention and engagement, we survey employees with the assistance of third-party
consultants, and take actions to address areas of employee concern.

We have identified other human capital priorities, including, among other things, providing competitive
wages and benefits and promoting an inclusive work environment. We are focused on efforts to elevate the
representation of women and U.S. minorities and foster an inclusive work environment that supports our large
global workforce and helps us innovate for our customers. Employee resource groups have been created to support
our diverse workforce. We also have taken actions with the goal of enhancing diversity, including setting diversity
targets for interview slates and recruiting at venues representing women, minorities, U.S. military veterans, and
LGBTQ+ talent.

Employee levels are managed to align with the pace of our business and management believes it has
sufficient human capital to operate its business successfully. We have approximately 17,800 employees located
around the world. Management believes that our employee relations are favorable.

A small portion of our U.S. employees are unionized, and outside the U.S., we have employees in certain
countries, particularly in Europe, that are represented by an employee representative organization, such as a union,
works council or employee association.

**Legal Proceedings**

We are subject to various litigations, claims and other proceedings that arise from time to time in the
ordinary course of business. We believe these actions are routine and incidental to the business. While the outcome
of these actions cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not believe that any will have a material adverse impact on
our business.

**CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS**

**JV NewCo Governance Documents**

In connection with the closing of the Acquisition (the “Closing”), (i) JV NewCo entered into an amended
and restated limited partnership agreement (the “JV NewCo LPA”) with its general partner, Emerald GP Holdings
G.P. LLC (“JV NewCo GP”), BCP Emerald and certain wholly owned holding company subsidiaries of Emerson,
and (ii) JV NewCo GP entered into an amended and restated limited liability company agreement (the “JV NewCo
GP LLCA” and, together with the JV NewCo LPA, the “Governance Documents”) with BCP Emerald and certain
wholly owned holding company subsidiaries of Emerson. Capitalized terms used in this section and not defined
herein have the meanings set forth in the JV NewCo LPA and the JV NewCo GP LLCA, as applicable. Upon the
closing of the Unit Purchase Transaction, Emerson’s rights under the Governance Documents will terminate (other
than in respect of certain indemnification and confidentiality obligations) and the Governance Documents will be
amended and restated to reflect such termination of rights.

Pursuant to the Governance Documents:

_Board Rights. JV NewCo is governed by the board of managers of JV NewCo GP (the “JV NewCo GP_
Board”), which will be comprised of up to ten managers and currently consists of three managers appointed by BCP
Emerald, two managers to be appointed by Emerson, the CEO of JV NewCo (who will be a non-voting manager),
and three independent managers appointed by BCP Emerald in consultation with Emerson. Each of BCP Emerald
and Emerson have the right to appoint up to three non-voting board observers. The rights of BCP Emerald and
Emerson to appoint managers to the JV NewCo GP Board (and the number of votes each manager may cast) are
subject to agreed step-downs in connection with transfers of their equity interests in JV NewCo (provided that each
will have the right to appoint at least one manager if they own more than 10% of JV NewCo). Actions of the JV
NewCo GP Board require consent of the managers holding a majority of the votes. The managers appointed by BCP
Emerald hold a majority of the votes of the JV NewCo GP Board, and such votes are controlled by the BCP Emerald
managers who are investment professionals of Blackstone.

_Consent Rights. Each of BCP Emerald and Emerson have consent rights over certain fundamental matters_
including, without limitation, related party transactions, any acquisition or disposition of assets or stock with a
purchase price in excess of $1 billion, and any incurrence of indebtedness that would exceed a certain specified pro
forma leverage ratio. The consent rights are subject to certain fall-away provisions.

_Transfer and Liquidity Rights._

Emerson will not be able to transfer any interest in JV NewCo, subject to certain exceptions, including
transfers (i) to certain affiliates, (ii) in an IPO or a change of control sale, (iii) following an IPO (subject to certain
restrictions discussed below), (iv) with the approval of the JV NewCo GP Board prior to the second anniversary of
the Closing, (v) subject to BCP Emerald’s “tag-along” rights, in an amount not to exceed 50% and 100% of its
interests in JV NewCo after the second and fifth anniversaries of the Closing, respectively (provided that Emerson
may not sell its interests to a competitor or activist investor), or (vi) pursuant to the exercise of Emerson’s customary
“tag-along” rights or in a change of control sale. Transfers by Emerson are generally subject to a “right of first offer”
by BCP Emerald over the interests proposed to be transferred.

BCP Emerald generally has the right to transfer any interest in JV NewCo, however, Emerson has
customary “tag-along” rights (as mentioned above) unless such transfer is (i) pursuant to customary permitted
transfer provisions, including to certain affiliates, (ii) in an IPO or a change of control sale, or (iii) in connection
with a syndication of BCP Emerald’s equity within six months of closing, subject to certain parameters. BCP
Emerald will also have the ability to force a change of control sale of JV NewCo; however, before the second
anniversary of the Closing, any such sale must generate an agreed upon return.

Emerson shall have the right to require JV NewCo to consummate a Qualified IPO after the fifth
anniversary of the Closing and BCP Emerald shall have the right to require JV NewCo to consummate a Qualified
IPO after the second anniversary of the Closing. Each of Emerson and BCP Emerald shall have the right to require


-----

JV NewCo to consummate a Non-Qualified IPO after the seventh anniversary of the Closing. If Emerson makes a
demand for JV NewCo to consummate an IPO (whether a Qualified IPO or a Non-Qualified IPO), BCP Emerald
shall have a right of first offer to purchase all of the common equity that Emerson owns. Certain volume-related
transfer restrictions will apply to Emerson in and following an IPO of JV NewCo, through a priority sell-down right
granted to BCP Emerald, until BCP Emerald has received an agreed amount of sale proceeds.

_Preemptive rights. Before an IPO, each party has preemptive rights with respect to any issuance of equity_
interests or debt securities in JV NewCo (subject to certain exceptions).

_Non-Compete. Until 24 months after Emerson’s ownership interest in JV NewCo falls below 10%,_
Emerson will not, directly or indirectly, engage in, or have an interest in, manage, control or provide financing to,
any business that competes with the Climate Technologies Business as conducted at the time of the Closing.
Exceptions to this non-compete are (i) acquisitions of a diversified business having not more than 10% of its sales
attributable to any competing business (or, if such sales exceed the 10% threshold, Emerson must divest below such
threshold within 12 months of such acquisition) and (ii) ownership of less than 5% of the equity interests of any
person engaged in a competing business.

_Non-Solicit and Non-Hire. Until 24 months after Emerson’s ownership interest in JV NewCo falls below_
10%, Emerson and JV NewCo may not solicit the following employees of the other: (i) executive or managerial
employees; and (ii) employees engaged in the provision of services to the other under the Transition Services
Agreement (discussed further below) in a senior, technical or managerial role, in each case of (i) and (ii), subject to
certain customary exceptions.

**Agreements with Management**

In connection with the Acquisition, we created two new incentive plans for our employees’ performance
and retention purposes, the Emerald JV Holdings L.P. 2023 Unit Incentive Plan and the Long-Term Incentive Plan.
Certain members of management and other employees participate in such plans.

We also have entered into new employment agreements with certain members of our management.

**Transition Services Agreement**

In connection with the Acquisition, Emerson and JV NewCo entered into a Transition Services Agreement
pursuant to which, following the Closing, each party provides the other party with various specified services on a
transitional basis at pre-agreed costs, consisting of the services provided between Emerson and the Climate
Technologies Business.

**Services Agreement**

In connection with the Closing, JV NewCo entered into a services agreement with Blackstone Management
Partners L.L.C. and Blackstone Capital Partners VIII L.P. (collectively, “BX Management”). Under the services
agreement, JV NewCo pays or reimburses BX Management and their affiliates for out-of-pocket costs and expenses
incurred on behalf of or in connection with the monitoring and evaluation of the operations of JV NewCo. JV
NewCo also indemnifies each of BX Management and certain of its related persons against, among other things,
losses and liabilities incurred in connection with or as a result of the services provided to JV NewCo or its affiliates
pursuant to the services agreement.

**Convertible PIK Preferred Equity**

In connection with the Closing, JV NewCo issued $2 billion aggregate initial liquidation preference of
shares of Convertible PIK Preferred Equity to BCP Emerald. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity rank senior in
rights upon liquidation, dissolution or winding up of JV NewCo to common stock and any other class or series of
equity securities of JV NewCo not specifically ranked senior to or pari passu with the Convertible PIK Preferred


-----

Equity. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is structurally subordinate to the Seller Notes and the third-party debt
financing.

In lieu of dividends, the initial aggregate liquidation preference of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity
accretes daily, compounding semi-annually, at a rate equal to 7% per annum.

The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is non-voting, except that approval of the holders of a majority of the
Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, voting as a separate class, is required for certain matters relating to the terms of
the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, the issuance of equity securities ranking senior to or pari passu with the
Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, and certain reorganization transactions involving JV NewCo.

The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is mandatorily convertible upon a Qualified IPO (as defined in the
JV NewCo GP LLCA) by JV NewCo or upon a Change of Control (as defined in the JV NewCo LPA) of JV
NewCo.

In an IPO, if the price per share of common stock sold in such IPO is greater than a 10% premium above
the common equity purchase price at the Closing, the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity will automatically convert
into common shares of the IPO Corporation. Otherwise, the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity will convert into a
cash-pay preferred instrument (the “Cash-Pay Preferred Equity”) paying dividends at a 9% annual rate. The CashPay Preferred Equity remains convertible into common stock up to the accreted amount of the Convertible PIK
Preferred Equity. If the Seller Notes remain outstanding after a Non-Qualified IPO, dividends on the Cash-Pay
Preferred Equity compound at a 9% rate, but are not paid until the Seller Notes are repaid in full.

BCP Emerald generally has the right to transfer the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, however, Emerson
will have customary “tag-along” rights in certain circumstances (as discussed above).

**Seller Notes**

In connection with the Closing, the Seller Notes Issuer issued two senior unsecured notes in aggregate
principal amount of $2.25 billion to an affiliate of Emerson. Pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement, the Seller
Notes Issuer will repurchase the Seller Notes issued to EMR Holdings. For a description of the Seller Notes and the
Seller Notes Repurchase, see “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness—Seller Notes” and “Summary—The
Transactions—Seller Notes Repurchase.”

**Corporate Campus Lease**

In connection with the Closing, that certain property located at 8000 and 8100 W. Florissant St. Louis,
Missouri (the “Corporate Campus”) was transferred by Emerson to a subsidiary of Emerson, which was, in turn,
transferred to a subsidiary of JV NewCo prior to the Closing. Beginning at the Closing, a portion of the Corporate
Campus has been leased from such subsidiary of JV NewCo, as landlord, to Emerson, as tenant (the “Campus
Lease”).

The Campus Lease has a term of three years (subject to certain extension rights). The base rent payable
under the Campus Lease is set at a rate per square foot of the Rentable Area (as defined in the Campus Lease). The
tenant under the Campus Lease is obligated to pay as additional rent its proportionate share of all real estate taxes,
insurance premiums, utility costs, repair and maintenance expenses and costs for ordinary capital improvements.

**Procedures with Respect to Review and Approval of Related Person Transactions**

From time to time, we may do business with certain companies affiliated with one or more members of the
Investor Group or Emerson. The JV NewCo GP Board has not adopted a formal written policy for the review and
approval of transactions with related persons. However, the JV NewCo GP Board expects to review and approve
transactions with related persons as appropriate. In addition, a noted above, JV NewCo must obtain the consent of
BCP Emerald and Emerson, as applicable, in connection with entry into certain related party transactions (subject to
certain exceptions).
