Term Loan Credit Agreement

On May 31, 2023, Merger Sub, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into a credit agreement
(the “Term Loan Credit Agreement”). Upon consummation of the Acquisition on the Closing Date, Merger Sub
merged with and into EMRLD Borrower, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, with EMRLD Borrower
surviving such merger. The Term Loan Credit Agreement permitted the Borrower to borrow $450.0 and $2,275.0
under new senior secured term loan facilities, the “Term Loan A Facility” and “Term Loan B Facility” respectively
and together, the “Term Loan Facilities”. The Term Loan A Facility matures on May 31, 2028 (the “Term Loan
A Maturity Date”), and amortizes in quarterly installments in an amount equal to, (i) commencing with the last
business day of the fiscal quarter ending September 30, 2025 and through and including the last business day
of the fiscal quarter ending June 30, 2027, 0.625% of the original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility
and (ii) thereafter and through and including the Term Loan A Maturity Date, of 1.875% of the original principal
amount of the Term Loan A Facility, with the remaining principal balance due in a lump sum on the Term Loan
A Maturity Date. The Term Loan B Facility matures on May 31, 2030 (the “Term Loan B Maturity Date”), and
commencing with fiscal quarter ending December 31, 2023, amortizes in equal quarterly installments of 0.25%

Dollar and Euro Notes

On May 19, 2023, Merger Sub and Emerald Co-Issuer Inc., a direct subsidiary of Merger Sub, issued senior
secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $2,275 and aggregate principal amount of €455 (or $500.0
U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.10 per €1.00). The Dollar Notes mature
on December 15, 2030, and bear interest at a rate of 6.625% per annum starting on May 19, 2023. The Euro
Notes mature on December 15, 2030, and bear interest at a rate of 6.375% per annum starting on May 19,
2023. The effective interest rates for the Dollar Notes and Euro Notes as of September 30, 2023, were 6.855%
and 6.567%, respectively. Principal on both the Dollar Notes and Euro Notes will be payable upon maturity. In
connection with the Dollar Notes and Euro Notes, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $36.5,
which was capitalized and is amortized over the term of the Dollar and Euro Notes.

ABL Credit Agreement

On May 31, 2023, the Merger Sub entered into a credit agreement (the “ABL Credit Agreement”). Upon
consummation of the Acquisition on the Closing Date, Merger Sub merged with and into EMRLD Borrower with
EMRLD Borrower surviving such merger. The ABL Credit Agreement provides the Company with access to an
up to $700.0 senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility” and, together
with the Term Loan Facilities, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). In connection with the Revolving Credit
Facility, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $21.5, which was capitalized in other assets
and is amortized over the term of the Revolving Credit Facility. Borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility
bear interest at Term SOFR Rate plus a margin of between 1.5% and 2.0% per annum (based on the Borrower’s
average excess availability), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. The Revolving Credit Facility also
requires a commitment fee of between 0.25% and 0.375% per annum (based on average daily revolving credit
exposure) on undrawn commitments to be paid quarterly in arrears. The Revolving Credit Facility terminates
on May 31, 2028. As of September 30, 2023, the Company had total capacity and available capacity of $397.3
and $293.4, respectively, under the Revolving Credit Facility.

The debt agreements governing the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Notes described above contain
covenants requiring compliance with, and govern among other things, restrictions on additional borrowings,
investments (including acquisitions) and distributions. As of September 30, 2023, and at all times during the
period, the Company was in compliance with its debt covenants.

Emerson Notes

On May 31, 2023, the Emerson Notes Issuer, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, issued two unsecured
notes, the Emerson Notes, to EMR Holdings, Inc., an affiliate of Emerson, in the aggregate amount of $2,250.0.
The Emerson Notes will mature on May 31, 2033. No debt issuance costs were incurred associated with the
issuance of the Emerson Notes. The Emerson Notes include provisions for the payment of interest on the
outstanding principal amount by adding the interest to the unpaid principal amount, which is referred to as paid


-----

in kind (“PIK”) interest. Interest compounds on a semi-annual basis. The stated interest rate of the Emerson
Notes is 5% per annum and the effective rate as of September 30, 2023, is 5.944%. Upon a change of control,
the Company is required to prepay the entire principal amount, plus accrued unpaid interest through the
prepayment date without any premium or penalty. The Emerson Notes are structurally subordinated to the
Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Notes.

The primary objective for the investment of pension assets is to secure participant retirement benefits by earning
a reasonable rate of return. Plan assets are invested consistent with the provisions of the prudence and
diversification rules of ERISA and with a long-term investment horizon. The Company continuously monitors
the value of assets by class and routinely rebalances to remain within target allocations. The equity strategy is
to minimize concentrations of risk by investing primarily in a mix of companies that are diversified across
geographies, market capitalization, style, sectors and industries worldwide. The approach for bonds
emphasizes investment-grade corporate and government debt with maturities matching a portion of the longer
duration pension liabilities. The bonds strategy also includes a high-yield element which is generally shorter in
duration. For diversification, a small portion of U.S. plan assets is allocated to private equity partnerships and
real asset fund investments, providing opportunities for above market returns. Leveraging techniques are not
used and the use of derivatives in any fund is limited and inconsequential. The fair values of defined benefit
plan assets as of September 30, organized by asset class and by the fair value hierarchy of ASC 820 as outlined

Asset Classes

U.S. equities reflect companies domiciled in the U.S., including multinational companies. International equites
are comprised of companies domiciled in developed nations outside the U.S. Emerging market equities are
comprised of companies domiciled in portions of Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America. Corporate bonds
represent investment-grade debt of issuers primarily from the U.S. Government bonds include investmentgrade instruments issued by federal, state and local governments, primarily in the U.S. Other includes cash,
interests in mixed asset funds investing in commodities, natural resources, agriculture, real estate and
infrastructure funds, life insurance contracts (U.S.), and shares in certain general investment funds of financial
institutions or insurance arrangements (non-U.S.) that typically ensure no market losses or provide for a small
minimum return guarantee.

Fair Value Hierarchy Categories

Valuations of Level 1 assets for all classes are based on quoted closing market prices from the principal
exchanges where the individual securities are traded. Cash is valued at cost, which approximates fair value.
Debt securities categorized as Level 2 assets are generally valued based on independent broker/dealer bids or
by comparison to other debt securities having similar durations, yields and credit ratings. Valuation techniques
and inputs for these assets include discounted cash flow analysis, earnings multiple approaches, recent
transactions, transfer restrictions, prevailing discount rates, volatilities, credit ratings and other factors. In the
Other class, interests in mixed asset funds are Level 2, and U.S. life insurance contracts and non-U.S. general
fund investments and insurance arrangements are Level 3. Investments measured at NAV are primarily
nonexchange-traded commingled or collective funds where the underlying securities have observable prices
available from active markets and typically provide liquidity daily or within a few days.

#### (14) SHARE-BASED COMPENSATION

Successor Period Share-based Compensation

In connection with the Acquisition, the Company created two new incentive plans for its employees’
performance and retention purposes, the Emerald JV Holdings L.P. 2023 Unit Incentive Plan ( “MIP”) and the
Long-Term Incentive Plan ( “LTIP”).

Long-Term Incentive Plan

Under the terms of the LTIP, employees are granted awards (the “LTIP Awards”) that become payable upon
meeting both a service condition (the “LTIP Service Condition”) and a liquidity event condition (the “LTIP
Liquidity Condition”). Awards issued under the LTIP have a maximum contractual term of the earlier to occur of
the date on which the vested award amount has been settled or 7 years. LTIP Awards are liability classified
since they allow for settlement in cash at the option of the Company.

Unit Incentive Plan

The MIP allows for the issuance of up to 466,881,550 units. Under the terms of the MIP, employees are awarded
stock options (“Options”) or Unit Appreciation Right awards (“UARs”). Awards issued under the MIP have a
maximum contractual term of 10 years. Options under the MIP are equity classified. UARs are liability classified
since they require settlement in cash.

During the four-months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the Company granted share-based payment
awards to its employees. Under the MIP, one half of the Options and UARs will vest in five (5) equal installments
on the first through fifth anniversaries of the vesting commencement date, so long as the employee remains
employed by the Company through the applicable vesting date (“Time-Vesting Units”). One half of the Options
and UARs granted under the MIP may vest upon a liquidity event based on the extent that Blackstone Capital
Partners VIII L.P. and its Affiliates (”Sponsor”) receives cash proceeds in respect of the Sponsor’s original
investment in an amount that meets certain multiples on invested capital and internal rate of return hurdles
subject to the recipient’s continued employment at the time the hurdles are met (“Performance-Vesting Units”).
Additionally, with regard to the UARs, both the Time-Vesting Units and Performance-Vesting Units may only be
exercised by an employee following a liquidity event.

The Company has elected to recognize forfeitures of Options and UARs as they occur in accordance with ASC
718, Compensation – Stock Compensation.

Options

Compensation expense for the Time-Vesting Units is recognized on a straight-line basis over the five-year
requisite service period. Performance-Vesting Units vest upon the achievement of certain liquidity events which
are not considered probable until consummated and, as such, no compensation expense has been recognized.

Share-based compensation expense for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) for the TimeVesting Options was $2.6 and was included in selling, general and administrative expenses.

Pricing Model Assumptions

The fair market values of the Time-Based Units and Performance-Based Units as of the grant date were
estimated using a Monte Carlo simulation model that utilized significant assumptions, including a risk-free rate
interest rate, expected volatility, expected life (in years), dividend rate, and discount for lack of marketability
(“DLOM”).These assumptions were determined using the methods discussed below.

   - The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. constant maturity treasury yield curve.

   - The expected volatility is estimated based on the volatility analysis of comparable companies.

   - The expected life (in years) is based on management’s estimate of the term to achieve a liquidity


-----

event.

   - The dividend rate is 0% because the Company does not expect for the foreseeable future to pay a
dividend.

   - The DLOM, which is an amount of value in ownership interest of a security that is lost due to its absence
of marketability. DLOM is often used not only to capture incremental rate of return that market
participants may require for investing in an interest that is not marketable (such as restricted stock) but
also to capture the incremental rate of return that market participants may require for investing in illiquid
interests. Several quantitative methods have been developed to estimate the DLOM for privately held
interests. The DLOM utilized in the Company’s pricing model is the Finnerty Model, which is a
commonly used method for calculating DLOM.

The range of assumptions used to determine the grant date fair value for the Time-Based Units and
Performance-Based Units is as follows:

#### (15) EQUITY INTERESTS

Partnership Interests in the Successor Period

The consolidated statements of equity reflect the issuance of general partner’s interest and limited partners’
interest in connection of the Acquisition as detailed in Note 2. As of September 30, 2023, the Company has
three main classes of units, General Partner Units, issued to the general partner (“General Partner”), and Class
P Units and Common Units, issued to the limited partners (“Limited Partners”).

As of the Acquisition Date, the Company estimated the value of the Class P and Class A Units (as defined
below) using an option pricing model in a Contingent Claim Analysis ("CCA") framework. A CCA allocates the
total available proceeds to various classes of equity securities at an expected liquidity event in accordance to
the rights and distribution preferences of the holders for a range of potential exit value outcomes.
The assumptions used in the CCA model for the Class P and Class A Units were as follows:

Dividend yield 0.0%
Expected volatility (based on observed volatility for comparable companies) 55.0%
Risk-free interest rate (based on US Constant Maturity Treasury Yield) 3.7%
Expected time to liquidity event (in years) 5.0
General Partner Units

The General Partner has the exclusive power and authority to manage and control the business and operations
of the Company. The General Partner is authorized to create additional classes of equity units and can issue


-----

an unlimited number of units of any class. As of September 30, 2023, the Company has a singular issued and
outstanding unit of General Partner Units.

Limited Partners’ Preferred Equity (Class P Units)

Class P Units do not contain voting rights (subject to certain standard exceptions) but have priority with respect
to rights on the distribution of assets and dividend upon any voluntary or involuntary liquidation and dissolution.
Class P Units accrete at an amount equal to 7% per annum. The holder of each Class P Unit has the option to,
if permitted by the Class P majority holder, convert the units into Class A-1 Units to participate in tag-along
rights of the General Partner LLC Agreement. In the occurrence of an initial public offering, if the price per share
of common stock is greater than the Conversion Price, all outstanding Class P Units will automatically convert
into an aggregate number of Class A-1 Units, determined by dividing the accreted amount of Class P Units by
the Conversion Price (“Mandatory IPO Conversion”). If an initial public offering occurs but does not meet the
conditions for Mandatory IPO Conversion, the class P majority holder can elect to have all of the Class P Units
converted to Class A-1 Units in the same manner as if a Mandatory IPO Conversion occurs, or, alternatively,
can elect to convert the Class P Units into a preferred security that pays interest at a 9% annual rate in cash,
on the terms and conditions set forth in the Company’s limited partnership agreement. Upon a change in control
or when the holder of Class P Unit elects to participate in tag-along rights, the Class P Units will automatically
convert into Class A-1 Units in the amount equal to the greater of the accreted amount of Class P Units divided
by the price per Class A-1 Unit or Conversion Price. The Company has 2.0 million Class P Units issued and
outstanding as of September 30, 2023.

Conversion Price

The “Conversion Price” for the Class P Units will be calculated as the product of 1.10 and the common equity
consideration in connection with the Acquisition divided by the number of Class A Units acquired by BCP Ruby
Limited Partners. The initial and current Conversion Price for the Class P Units is $1.1 dollar per unit. The
Conversion Price is subject to adjustment upon the occurrence of certain anti-dilutive common stock events,
including stock splits, the issuance of common stock dividends.

Limited Partners’ Common Equity (Common Units)

Common Units consist of Class A-1 Units and Class A-2 Units. The Class A-2 Units are issued to management
and do not contain voting rights. Common Units rank subsequent to holders of Class P units in any distributions
or dividends. As of September 30, 2023, the Company has approximately 4,201.9 million Class A-1 units and
2.0 million Class A-2 units issued and outstanding.

#### (17) CONTINGENT LIABILITIES AND COMMITMENTS

The Company is a party to a number of pending legal proceedings and claims, including those involving general
and product liability (including asbestos), and other matters. The Company accrues for such liabilities when it
is probable that future costs will be incurred, and such costs can be reasonably estimated. Accruals are based
on developments to date; management's estimates of the outcomes of these matters; the Company's
experience in contesting, litigating and settling similar matters; and any related insurance coverage. While the
Company believes a material adverse impact is unlikely, it is not possible to predict the ultimate outcome of
these matters. Given the inherent uncertainty of litigation, a remote possibility exists that a future development
could have a material adverse impact on the Company.

The Company engages an outside expert to develop an actuarial estimate of its expected costs to resolve all
pending and future asbestos claims, including defense costs, as well as its related insurance receivable. The
reserve for asbestos litigation, which is recorded on an undiscounted basis, was $53.8 and $17.8 and the
insurance receivable was $26.3 and $16.6 as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and September 30, 2022
(Predecessor), respectively. As part of the Transaction Agreement, Emerson has indemnified the Company for
asbestos claims filed against the Company for up to 7 years after the Acquisition Date, up to a maximum of
$75.0; with Emerson having the right to offset any such amount against the Emerson Notes. The Company
anticipates the total amount of claims filed during the 7-year period will be $28.5 with a related insurance
receivable of $10.0, and therefore an indemnification receivable equal to $18.5 has been recorded as of
Acquisition Date and September 30, 2023.


-----

The Company is also responsible for environmental remediation at various facilities presently or formerly
operated by the Company. The environmental remediation liability is recorded based upon the best estimate of
costs to be incurred in light of the progress made in determining the magnitude of remediation costs, the timing,
and extent of remedial actions required by governmental authorities. The actual costs the Company will incur
are dependent on final determination of contamination and required remedial action, negotiations with
governmental authorities with respect to cleanup levels, changes in regulatory requirements, innovations in
investigatory and remedial technologies, effectiveness of remedial technologies employed, the ability of other
responsible parties to pay, and any insurance or other third-party recoveries. As of September 30, 2023
(Successor), the Company has recorded, on an undiscounted basis, a total liability of $16.6 for environmental
remediation costs regarding these facilities. Approximately $3.7 and $12.9 was recorded in accrued expenses
and other long-term liabilities, respectively. As of September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) the total liability was $14.3,
approximately $3.0 and $11.3 was recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively.
As of September 30, 2023 (Successor), there were no other known contingent liabilities (including guarantees
and other claims) that management believes will be material in relation to the Company’s financial statements,
nor were there any material commitments outside the normal course of business.

Basis for Opinion

These consolidated and combined financial statements are the responsibility of the Company’s management.
Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated and combined financial statements based on
our audits. We are a public accounting firm registered with the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board

combined financial statements. Our audits also included evaluating the accounting principles used and

and combined financial statements. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.

Sufficiency of audit evidence over net sales

As discussed in Notes 1, 2 and 15 to the Company’s consolidated and combined financial statements, and
disclosed in the consolidated and combined statements of earnings, the Company recorded $5.1 billion of
net sales in 2022.

We identified the evaluation of the sufficiency of audit evidence over net sales as a critical audit matter. Net
sales are recognized primarily from the sale of manufactured products at locations in multiple countries
around the world. Evaluating the sufficiency of audit evidence obtained required subjective auditor
judgment because of the geographical dispersion of the Company’s net sales generating activities. This
included determining the locations at which procedures were performed and evaluating the evidence
obtained over net sales.

The following are the primary procedures we performed to address this critical audit matter. We applied
auditor judgment to determine the nature and extent of procedures to be performed over net sales,
including the determination of the Company locations at which those procedures were to be performed. We
evaluated the design and tested the operating effectiveness of certain internal controls related to the
Company’s net sales process. At each location where procedures were performed, we assessed the
recorded net sales by selecting a sample of transactions and compared the amounts recognized for
consistency with underlying documentation, including contracts with customers and other third-party
evidence. We evaluated the sufficiency of audit evidence obtained by assessing the results of procedures
performed, including the appropriateness of the nature and extent of such evidence.

We have served as the Company’s auditor since 2022.

#### (1) SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES

Description of Business

Climate Technologies (CT or the Company) operates as a business of Emerson Electric Co.’s (Emerson)
Commercial & Residential Solutions platform. CT is a leading provider of compression products, electronics,
software and solutions across many applications within Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning and
Refrigeration (HVACR) and other heating applications, food service and retail, transportation, and
healthcare/life sciences. CT’s compression technologies enable higher efficiency in commercial and
residential HVAC units, as well as in commercial refrigeration units. CT also has a solution portfolio that
manages, monitors and controls refrigeration units in the commercial setting, as well as software solutions
that measure and monitor temperature conditions of refrigerated goods in transit.

The Proposed Transaction

On October 31, 2022, Emerson announced an agreement to sell a majority stake in Climate Technologies
to private equity funds managed by Blackstone in a transaction valued at $14.0 billion. Emerson will receive
upfront, pre-tax cash proceeds of approximately $9.5 billion and a note of $2.25 billion at close, while
retaining a 45 percent non-controlling common equity ownership interest in a new standalone joint venture
between Emerson and Blackstone. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of calendar year
2023, subject to regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions.

Basis of Presentation and Principles of Consolidation

The Company has historically operated as part of Emerson and not as a stand-alone entity. These
consolidated and combined financial statements present the historical financial position, results of
operations, and cash flows of the Company as if it had operated on a standalone basis subject to Emerson’s
control and include all accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries and affiliates on a consolidated basis.
Intercompany transactions, profits and balances among CT entities have been eliminated in consolidation.
These financial statements were derived from Emerson’s financial statements and accounting records and
have been prepared in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America (U.S. GAAP). Sale and purchase transactions between the Company and other Emerson affiliates
are included in the financial statements. See Note 12.

As a business of Emerson, CT has been charged for costs directly related to the Company and has been
allocated a portion of Emerson’s general corporate costs. All of these costs are reflected in these
consolidated and combined financial statements. The Company participates in various Emerson programs
which include information technology services, employee benefits, medical insurance, and other programs.
Costs associated with these programs are charged to the Company based on Emerson’s actual cost and
the Company’s relative level of usage. The Company also utilizes Emerson’s global shared service centers
and is charged for direct costs and its share of facilities overhead.

Emerson provides certain oversight and support services, including assistance with management strategy,
logistics, marketing, finance, treasury, tax, human resources, legal and other activities. Emerson also
charges royalties for use of Emerson’s trademarks and trade names and supply chain services. A charge
for these services and royalties has been allocated to the Company based principally on revenue. While
management believes the methodologies and assumptions used to allocate these costs are reasonable,
the financial statements do not purport to represent the financial position, or the results of operations,
changes in equity, and cash flows of the Company in the future, or what they would have been had the
Company operated as a stand-alone entity during the periods presented.


-----

Emerson utilizes a centralized treasury function which manages the working capital and financing needs of
all of its business operations. This function oversees a cash pooling arrangement which sweeps
participating CT cash accounts into pooled Emerson cash accounts on a daily basis. Pooled cash and nontrade intercompany balances attributable to Emerson have not been presented as assets and liabilities in
the accompanying consolidated and combined financial statements. These balances are reflected as "Net
parent investment" in the equity section of the consolidated and combined balance sheets. Changes in
these balances are reflected as "Net transfer to Emerson'' in the financing activities section of the
consolidated and combined statements of cash flows. Cash and cash equivalents from CT entities not
participating in the Emerson centralized treasury function and specifically attributable to the Company have
been reflected in the consolidated and combined financial statements.

Use of Estimates

The preparation of the consolidated and combined financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP
requires management to make estimates and assumptions that could affect the reported amounts of assets,
liabilities, revenue and expenses for the periods presented. Actual results could differ from those estimates.

Foreign Currency

The consolidated and combined financial statements are presented in U.S. dollars, which is the Company’s
reporting currency. The functional currency for the Company’s operations in Mexico, Argentina, Thailand,
Hong Kong, Denmark and the majority in the Middle East is U.S. dollars while most other non-U.S.
operations use the local currency. Adjustments resulting from translating local currency financial statements
into U.S. dollars are reflected in accumulated other comprehensive income. Transactions denominated in
currencies other than the functional currencies are subject to changes in exchange rates with resulting
gains/losses recorded in net earnings.

Cash and Cash Equivalents

Cash and cash equivalents consist of highly-liquid investments with original maturities of three months or
less.

Receivables and Allowance for Credit Losses

Receivables are shown net of allowance for credit losses. The Company monitors customer-specific
payment and write-off history as well as forward-looking trends and macro-economic factors to estimate an
allowance for credit losses.

Inventories

Inventories are primarily stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value and are valued based on standard
costs which approximate average costs. Cost standards are revised at the beginning of each fiscal year.
The annual effect of resetting standards plus operating variances incurred during each period are allocated
between inventories and recognized in cost of sales as products are sold. Following are the components
of inventories as of September 30:

The Company records investments in land, buildings, and machinery and equipment at cost. Depreciation

assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate the

estimated fair values if the sum of expected future undiscounted cash flows of the related assets is less

Goodwill and Other Intangibles

Assets and liabilities acquired in business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method
and recorded at their respective fair values. Goodwill represents the excess of consideration paid over total
fair value of the net assets acquired. The Company conducts its annual impairment test of goodwill in the
fourth quarter and between tests if events or circumstances indicate a reporting unit’s fair value may be
less than its carrying value. If an initial assessment indicates it is more likely than not goodwill might be
impaired, it is evaluated by comparing the reporting unit’s estimated fair value to its carrying value. An
impairment charge would be recorded for the amount by which the carrying value of the reporting unit
exceeds its estimated fair value. Estimated fair values are developed primarily under an income approach
that discounts estimated future cash flows using risk adjusted interest rates, as well as earnings multiples
or other techniques as warranted. Fair values are subject to changes in underlying economic conditions.

All of the Company’s identifiable intangible assets are subject to amortization on a straight-line basis over
their estimated useful lives. Identifiable intangible assets consist of capitalized software, intellectual
property and customer relationships and are also subject to evaluation for potential impairment if events or
circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.

No goodwill or intangible asset impairment was recorded for any of the periods presented.

Leases

The Company leases offices; manufacturing facilities and equipment; and transportation, information
technology, and office equipment primarily under operating lease arrangements. The Company determines
whether an arrangement is, or contains, a lease at contract inception. An arrangement contains a lease if
the Company has the right to direct the use of and obtain substantially all of the economic benefits of an
identified asset. Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities are recognized at lease commencement based on
the present value of lease payments over the lease term. Leases with an initial term of 12 months or less
are not recognized on the balance sheet and are recorded as short-term lease expenses. The discount rate
used to calculate present value is the Company’s incremental borrowing rate based on the lease term and
the economic environment of the applicable country or region.

Certain leases have renewal options or options to terminate prior to lease expiration, which are included in
the measurement of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities when it is reasonably certain they will be
exercised. The Company has elected to account for lease and non-lease components as a single lease
component for its offices and manufacturing facilities. Some lease arrangements include payments that are
adjusted periodically based on actual charges incurred for common area maintenance, utilities, taxes and
insurance, or changes in an index or rate referenced in the lease. The fixed portion of these payments is
included in the measurement of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities at lease commencement, while the
variable portion is recorded as variable lease expense. The Company’s leases do not contain material
residual value guarantees or restrictive covenants.

Noncontrolling Interests in a Subsidiary

The Company holds a 51% controlling financial interest in Alliance Compressors LLC (“Alliance”) and
therefore, the financial position, results of operations and cash flows of Alliance have been included in the


-----

Company’s consolidated and combined financial statements. The remaining 49% interest in Alliance are
accounted for as noncontrolling interests in subsidiary in the Company’s consolidated and combined
financial statements. The Alliance joint venture agreement includes contingent put options that could require
the Company to purchase the noncontrolling interests in the event of a change in control of Emerson or
Alliance. In the event that a change of control occurs, and the put options are exercised by holders of the
49% interests, the Company would be required to purchase the noncontrolling interests in Alliance for
approximately $130.

Net Parent Investment

The net parent investment balance included in the consolidated and combined balance sheets represents
Emerson’s historical investment in the Company, the Company’s accumulated net earnings after income
taxes, and the net effect of transactions with Emerson.

Revenue Recognition

In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 606, Revenue from Contracts with
Customers, the Company evaluates its contracts with customers to identify the promised goods or services
and recognize revenue for the identified performance obligations at the amount the Company expects to
be entitled to in exchange for those goods or services. A performance obligation is a promise in a contract
to transfer a distinct good or service to a customer. Revenue is recognized when, or as performance
obligations are satisfied, and control has transferred to the customer, typically when products are shipped
or delivered, title and risk of loss pass to the customer, and the Company has a present right to payment.

The vast majority of the Company's revenues are performance obligations related to the sale of
manufactured products which are recognized at a point in time when control transfers in accordance with
shipping terms. In limited circumstances, contracts include multiple performance obligations, where
revenue is recognized separately for each good or service, as well as contracts where revenue is
recognized over time as control transfers to the customer.

For revenues recognized over time, the Company typically uses an input method to determine progress
and recognize revenue, based on costs incurred. The Company believes costs incurred closely correspond
with its performance under the contract and the transfer of control to the customer.

In sales arrangements that involve multiple performance obligations, revenue is allocated based on the
relative standalone selling price for each performance obligation. Observable selling prices from actual
transactions are used whenever possible. In other instances, the Company determines the standalone
selling price based on third-party pricing or management's best estimate.

Payment terms vary but are generally short-term in nature. The Company’s long-term contracts, where
revenue is generally recognized over time, are billed as work progresses in accordance with the contract
terms and conditions, either at periodic intervals or upon achievement of certain milestones. The timing of
revenue recognition and billings under these contracts results in either unbilled receivables (contract
assets) when revenue recognized exceeds billings, or customer advances (contract liabilities) when billings
exceed revenue recognized. Unbilled receivables are reclassified to accounts receivable when an
unconditional right to consideration exists, typically when a milestone in the contract is achieved. The
Company does not evaluate whether the transaction price includes a significant financing component for
contracts where the time between cash collection and performance is less than one year.

Certain arrangements with customers include variable consideration, typically in the form of rebates, cash
discounts or penalties. Other than standard product warranty provisions, sales arrangements provide no
other post shipment obligations on the Company. In most instances, returns are limited to product quality
issues. The Company records a reduction to revenue at the time of sale to reflect the ultimate amount of
consideration it expects to receive. The Company’s estimates are updated quarterly based on historical
experience, trend analysis, and expected market conditions. Variable consideration is typically not
constrained at the time revenue is recognized. See Notes 2 and 15 for additional information about the
Company’s revenues.


-----

In the years presented, the Company had one significant customer who accounted for over 10 percent of
net sales. This customer had approximately 12 to 13 percent of net sales in 2022, 2021, and 2020.

The Company records amounts billed to customers for the costs of shipping and handling in sales
transactions as revenue and such costs are not considered separate performance obligations. Shipping
and handling costs incurred by the Company were $35.5, $50.6 and $39.8 for 2022, 2021 and 2020,
respectively, and were reported in selling, general and administrative expenses.

Warranty

Warranties largely provide assurance that the product will function as intended and generally extend for a
period of one to two years from the date of sale. Warranties vary by product line and are competitive for the
markets in which the Company operates. Provisions for warranty expense are estimated at the time of sale
based on historical experience and adjusted quarterly for any known issues that may arise. Warranty costs
were, $29.7, $27.5 and $32.4, respectively, or approximately 0.6 percent, 0.6 percent and 0.9 percent of
net sales in 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

Supplier Finance Program

Emerson facilitates a voluntary supplier finance program (the "Program") to provide certain Company
suppliers with the opportunity to sell receivables due from the Company to the participating financial
institution in the Program. Such sales are conducted at the sole discretion of both the suppliers and the
financial institution on a non-recourse basis at a rate that leverages Emerson’s credit rating and thus might
be more beneficial to the supplier. The Company's responsibility is limited to making payment on the terms
originally negotiated with its suppliers, regardless of whether the suppliers sell their receivables to the
financial institution. Emerson and the Company do not enter into any agreements with suppliers regarding
their participation in the Program. The amount owed to the participating financial institution under the
Program and included in accounts payable was $170.8 at September 30, 2022 and $161.2 at September
30, 2021.

Fair Value Measurement

ASC 820, Fair Value Measurement, establishes a formal hierarchy and framework for measuring certain
financial statement items at fair value, and requires disclosures about fair value measurements and the
reliability of valuation inputs. Under ASC 820, measurement assumes the transaction to sell an asset or
transfer a liability occurs in the principal or at least the most advantageous market for that asset or liability.
Within the hierarchy, Level 1 instruments use observable market prices for the identical item in active
markets and have the most reliable valuations. Level 2 instruments are valued through broker/dealer
quotation or through market-observable inputs for similar items in active markets, including forward and
spot prices, interest rates and volatilities. Level 3 instruments are valued using inputs not observable in an
active market, such as company-developed future cash flows, and are considered the least reliable.
Valuations for all the Company’s financial instruments fall within Level 2. See Note 7. Carrying value
approximates fair value for cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and accounts payable.

Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities

In the normal course of business, the Company is exposed to changes in foreign currency exchange rates
and commodity prices. The Company’s foreign currency exposures relate to transactions denominated in
currencies that differ from the functional currencies of its subsidiaries, principally Mexican pesos. Foreign
exchange forwards are utilized, as needed, to hedge foreign currency exposures impacting sales or cost
of sales transactions, firm commitments, or the fair value of assets and liabilities. Commodity exposures
are price fluctuations on forecasted purchases of copper and aluminum. All derivatives are associated with
specific underlying exposures and the Company does not hold derivatives for trading or speculative
purposes. The initial duration of hedge positions is less than two years.

All derivatives are accounted for under ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging, and recognized at fair value.
For derivatives hedging variability in future cash flows, any gain or loss is deferred in equity and recognized
when the underlying hedged transaction impacts earnings. The Company’s foreign currency derivatives
and most commodity derivatives qualify for hedge accounting. Gains or losses on derivative instruments


-----

that do not receive hedge accounting treatment under ASC 815 are recognized in the income statement
immediately.

Income Taxes

The Company’s operations have historically been included in Emerson’s combined U.S. and non-U.S.
income tax returns in most locations. Income tax expense included in the financial statements has been
calculated following the separate return method, which applies ASC 740, Income Taxes, as if the Company
was a stand-alone enterprise and a separate taxpayer for the periods presented. The calculation of income
taxes on a separate return basis requires considerable judgment and the use of both estimates and
allocations that affect the calculation of certain tax liabilities and the determination of the recoverability of
certain deferred tax assets, which arise from temporary differences between the tax and financial statement
recognition of revenue and expenses. As a result, the Company’s deferred income tax rate and deferred
tax balances may differ from those in Emerson’s historical results.

The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of ASC 740. Under this
approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported
amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid. Deferred taxes result from differences between the
financial statement and tax basis of the Company’s assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted
rates in effect for the year in which the temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
Valuation allowances are recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that a tax
benefit will not be realized. The tax carryforwards reflected in the Company’s consolidated and combined
financial statements have been determined using the separate return method.

The complexity of tax regulations requires assessments of uncertainties in estimating taxes the Company
will ultimately pay. The Company recognizes liabilities for anticipated tax audit uncertainties in the U.S. and
other tax jurisdictions based on its estimate of whether, and the extent to which additional taxes would be
due on a separate return basis. Tax liabilities are presented net of any related tax loss carryforwards.

The Company also provides for income taxes, net of any potentially available foreign tax credits, on
earnings intended to be repatriated from foreign subsidiaries. The undistributed earnings of foreign
subsidiaries as of September 30, 2022 are considered permanently invested or otherwise indefinitely
retained for continuing international operations. Recognition of income taxes on undistributed foreign
earnings, if any, would be triggered by a decision to repatriate earnings. Determination of the amount of
taxes that might be paid on any undistributed earnings if eventually remitted is not practicable.

Adopted Accounting Pronouncements

Effective October 1, 2021, the Company adopted three accounting standard updates which had an
immaterial or no impact on the Company’s financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2022.
These included:

 Updates to ASC 805, Business Combinations, which clarify the accounting for contract assets and
liabilities assumed in a business combination. In general, this will result in contract liabilities being
recognized at their historical amounts under ASC 606, rather than at fair value in accordance with
the general requirements of ASC 805.

 Updates to ASC 740, Income Taxes, which require the recognition of a franchise tax that is partially
based on income as an income-based tax with any incremental amount as a non-income based
tax. These updates also make certain changes to intra-period tax allocation principles and interim
tax calculations.

 Updates to ASC 321, Equity Securities, ASC 323 Investments- Equity Method and Joint Ventures,
and ASC 815 Derivatives and Hedging, which clarify how to account for the transition into and out
of the equity method of accounting when evaluating observable transactions.


-----

In fiscal 2021, the Company adopted two accounting standard updates and one new accounting standard
and in fiscal 2020 adopted updates to ASC 815, all of which had an immaterial or no impact on the
Company’s financial statements. These included:

 Updates to ASC 350, Intangibles – Goodwill and Other, which eliminate the requirement to measure
impairment based on the implied fair value of goodwill compared to the carrying amount of a
reporting unit’s goodwill. Instead, goodwill impairment will be measured as the excess of a reporting
unit carrying amount over its estimated fair value.

 Updates to ASC 350, Intangibles- Goodwill and Other, which align the requirements for capitalizing
implementation costs incurred in a software hosting arrangement with the requirements for costs
incurred to developer obtain internal-use software.

 Adoption of ASC 326, Financial Instruments – Credit Losses, which amends the impairment model
by requiring entities to use a forward-looking approach to estimate lifetime expected credit losses
on certain types of financial instruments, including trade receivables.

 Updates to ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging, which permit hedging certain contractually specified
risk components. The updates eliminate the requirement to separately measure and report hedge
ineffectiveness and simplify hedge documentation and effectiveness assessment requirements.

The primary objective for the investment of pension assets is to secure participant retirement benefits by
earning a reasonable rate of return. Plan assets are invested consistent with the provisions of the prudence
and diversification rules of ERISA and with a long-term investment horizon. The Company continuously
monitors the value of assets by class and routinely rebalances to remain within target allocations. The
equity strategy is to minimize concentrations of risk by investing primarily in a mix of companies that are
diversified across geographies, market capitalization, style, sectors and industries worldwide. The approach
for bonds emphasizes investment-grade corporate and government debt with maturities matching a portion
of the longer duration pension liabilities. The bonds strategy also includes a high-yield element which is
generally shorter in duration. For diversification, a small portion of U.S. plan assets is allocated to private
equity partnerships and real asset fund investments, providing opportunities for above market returns.
Leveraging techniques are not used and the use of derivatives in any fund is limited and inconsequential.

Asset Classes

U.S. equities reflect companies domiciled in the U.S., including multinational companies. International
equities are comprised of companies domiciled in developed nations outside the U.S. Emerging market
equities are comprised of companies domiciled in portions of Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America.
Corporate bonds represent investment-grade debt of issuers primarily from the U.S. Government bonds
include investment-grade instruments issued by federal, state and local governments, primarily in the U.S.
Other includes cash, interests in mixed asset funds investing in commodities, natural resources, agriculture,
real estate and infrastructure funds, life insurance contracts (U.S.), and shares in certain general investment
funds of financial institutions or insurance arrangements (non-U.S.) that typically ensure no market losses
or provide for a small minimum return guarantee.

Fair Value Hierarchy Categories

Valuations of Level 1 assets for all classes are based on quoted closing market prices from the principal
exchanges where the individual securities are traded. Cash is valued at cost, which approximates fair value.
Debt securities categorized as Level 2 assets are generally valued based on independent broker/dealer
bids or by comparison to other debt securities having similar durations, yields and credit ratings. Valuation
techniques and inputs for these assets include discounted cash flow analysis, earnings multiple
approaches, recent transactions, transfer restrictions, prevailing discount rates, volatilities, credit ratings
and other factors. In the Other class, interests in mixed asset funds are Level 2, and U.S. life insurance
contracts and non-U.S. general fund investments and insurance arrangements are Level 3. Investments
measured at NAV are primarily nonexchange-traded commingled or collective funds where the underlying
securities have observable prices available from active markets and typically provide liquidity daily or within
a few days. The NAV category also includes fund investments in private equities, real estate and
infrastructure where the fair value of the underlying assets is determined by the investment manager. Total
unfunded commitments for the private equity funds were approximately $6.0 at September 30, 2022. These
investments cannot be redeemed, but instead the funds will make distributions through liquidation of the
underlying assets, which is expected to occur over approximately the next 10 years. The real estate and
infrastructure funds typically offer quarterly redemption.

#### (12) RELATED-PARTY TRANSACTIONS

As a business of Emerson, the Company has been charged for costs directly attributable to CT and
allocated a portion of Emerson’s general corporate costs. All these costs are reflected in the Company’s
financial statements. Management believes the methodologies and assumptions used to allocate costs to
the Company are reasonable.

Emerson maintains a centralized information technology function that supports its business units. Services
provided include application hosting, network support, network security, messaging and technology related
services. Charges to the Company for these services are based on Emerson’s cost and the Company’s
actual usage. Emerson administers a medical insurance program for its U.S. employees in which the
Company participates and for which it records the cost of claims incurred each period. The Company
participates in other Emerson programs including, but not limited to, workers’ compensation and general
and product liability insurance. Other Emerson programs are charged to the Company based on costs
incurred and usage. The Company utilizes Emerson global shared service centers that host Companydedicated resources providing customer facing support, engineering and back office financial services.
Costs for these resources are charged directly to the Company, with the majority relating to employee
compensation and benefits and the remaining portion relating to facility overhead. In addition, general
corporate costs incurred by Emerson and trademark and tradename royalties and supply chain services
are allocated to the Company primarily based on its proportionate share of Emerson’s total consolidated
revenue, and include the cost of support functions such as procurement, logistics, marketing, human
resources, legal, finance, internal audit and other Emerson corporate functions.

#### (13) CONTINGENT LIABILITIES AND COMMITMENTS

The Company is a party to a number of pending legal proceedings and claims, including those involving
general and product liability (including asbestos), and other matters. The Company accrues for such
liabilities when it is probable that future costs (including legal fees and expenses) will be incurred and such
costs can be reasonably estimated. Accruals are based on developments to date; management's estimates
of the outcomes of these matters; the Company's experience in contesting, litigating and settling similar
matters; and any related insurance coverage. While the Company believes a material adverse impact is
unlikely, it is not possible to predict the ultimate outcome of these matters. Given the inherent uncertainty
of litigation, a remote possibility exists that a future development could have a material adverse impact on
the Company.

The Company engages an outside expert to develop an actuarial estimate of its expected costs to resolve
all pending and future asbestos claims, including defense costs, as well as its related insurance receivable.
The reserve for asbestos litigation, which is recorded on an undiscounted basis, was $17.8 and $27.8 and
the insurance receivable was $16.6 and $22.7 as of September 30, 2022 and 2021, respectively.

The Company is also responsible for environmental remediation at various facilities presently or formerly
operated by the Company. The environmental remediation liability is recorded based upon the best estimate
of costs to be incurred in light of the progress made in determining the magnitude of remediation costs, the
timing, and extent of remedial actions required by governmental authorities. As of September 30, 2022, the
Company estimated total liability for environmental remediation costs ranges from a minimum of $6.8 to a
maximum of $17.1. The actual costs the Company will incur are dependent on final determination of
contamination and required remedial action, negotiations with governmental authorities with respect to
cleanup levels, changes in regulatory requirements, innovations in investigatory and remedial technologies,
effectiveness of remedial technologies employed, the ability of other responsible parties to pay, and any
insurance or other third-party recoveries.

As of September 30, 2022, the Company estimated a total liability of $14.3 for environmental remediationand related legal costs regarding these facilities. Approximately $3.0 and $11.3 is recorded in accrued
expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively. As of September 30, 2021, approximately $2.8 and
$11.4 is recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively.

As of September 30, 2022, there were no other known contingent liabilities (including guarantees, taxes
and other claims) that management believes will be material in relation to the Company’s financial
statements, nor were there any material commitments outside the normal course of business.

#### (15) BUSINESS SEGMENT INFORMATION

Climate Technologies is a leading provider of products and solutions for many areas of the climate control
industry, including residential heating and cooling, commercial air conditioning, commercial and industrial
refrigeration, and cold chain management. The business segments are primarily organized by product
offering. A description of the product and service offerings by each segment follows.

HVACR Tech
HVACR Technologies (HVACR Tech) provides highly engineered and efficient heating, air conditioning,
and refrigeration compression products, solutions and controls for commercial, residential, and industrial
applications. These products include scroll, reciprocating, centrifugal and screw compressors, including
highly efficient two-stage and variable speed scroll compressors along with temperature sensors and
controls. Residential applications include air conditioning units and heat pumps. Commercial applications
include cold storage in supermarkets and convenience stores, space heating and cooling in commercial
and office buildings, data center cooling, as well as transportation heating and cooling. Industrial
applications support renewable natural gas capture and CO2 refrigeration.

Comfort Control
Comfort Control offers heating and air conditioning products that create comfortable environments in all
types of buildings, including standard, programmable and Wi-Fi thermostats; monitoring equipment and
electronic controls for gas and electric heating systems; gas values for furnaces and water heaters; and
ignition systems for furnaces.

Cold Chain
Cold Chain provides product and services that digitally control and remotely monitor refrigeration units in
grocery stores and other food distribution outlets to reduce energy consumption and maintenance. Its


-----

products and services also include cargo and transportation monitoring solutions which monitor
temperature throughout the cold chain to ensure quality and safety as food travels from growers to
processing and distribution facilities, and finally to retail points of sale.

The primary income measure used for assessing segment performance and making operating decisions is
earnings before interest and income taxes. Certain expenses are reported at Climate Technologies
Corporate, including stock compensation. Corporate and other includes headquarters management costs,
depreciation and amortization of corporate assets, and restructuring. Intersegment selling prices
approximate market prices. Summarized below is information about the Company’s operations by business

**(1) SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES**

**_Description of Business_**

Emerald JV Holdings L.P. (“Emerald,” “JV NewCo,” or the “Company”) is a leading provider of compression
technologies, electronics and controls products, as well as components, software and solutions that broadly serve
applications across the Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning and Refrigeration (“HVACR”) and Industrial
industries. The Company’s businesses are primarily organized by product offering. The Company’s products are
organized into two broad categories - HVACR Technologies and Electronics and Controls. Geographically, we
organize through three world areas - Americas, Asia, Middle East and Africa (“AMEA”) and Europe. The served
applications include, among others, heating and cooling including heat pump applications, food service / retail /
industrial refrigeration, perishable goods, transportation, healthcare / life sciences, and renewable energy. The
Company’s compression technologies enable higher efficiency in commercial and residential HVAC units, as well as
in commercial and industrial refrigeration units. The Company also has a solution portfolio that manages, monitors
and controls refrigeration units in the commercial setting, as well as software solutions that measure and monitor
temperature conditions of refrigerated goods in transit. The Company’s industrial products are designed into
renewable energy processes including RNG and Biogas applications. In general, the company’s technologies and
solutions address global trends, including (i) the decarbonization and increased energy efficiency of heating, cooling,
refrigeration, and industrial processes, (ii) the drive towards lower-GWP refrigerants, and (iii) the efficient transport
of perishable goods including food and medicine. The Company now operates under the Copeland brand, as well as
the Sensi, Verdant, Vilter and White-Rodgers sub-brands.

Emerald JV Holdings L.P., a Delaware limited partnership, was formed by Emerson Electric Co. (“Emerson”), to hold
its Climate Technologies Business (“Climate Technologies”) in connection with the acquisition of a majority stake in
Climate Technologies (the “Acquisition”) by certain investment funds affiliated with Blackstone Inc. (“Blackstone”).
The Company currently holds Climate Technologies, after the completion of certain restructuring steps undertaken by
Emerson to transfer Climate Technologies to JV NewCo (the “Restructuring”). As Emerald JV Holdings L.P. did not
have any previous operations, Climate Technologies is viewed as the predecessor to the Company and its consolidated
subsidiaries. Accordingly, these consolidated financial statements include certain historical consolidated financial and
other data for Climate Technologies for periods prior to the completion of the Acquisition.

**_Basis of Presentation and Principles of Consolidation_**

As a result of the Acquisition as further discussed in Note 2, periods prior to May 31, 2023 reflect the financial
statements of Climate Technologies prior to the Acquisition (referred to herein as the “Predecessor” period). Periods
subsequent to May 31, 2023 reflect the financial statements of the Company after the Acquisition (referred to herein
as the “Successor” period). The Company’s assets and liabilities were adjusted to fair value on the closing date of the
Acquisition. Due to the change in the basis of accounting, the consolidated and combined financial statements for the
Predecessor and the consolidated financial statements for the Successor are not comparable. Where applicable, a
“black line” separates the Successor and Predecessor periods to highlight the lack of comparability.

The Successor Statement of Operations reflects the results of the business following the closing of the Acquisition.
However, on May 19, 2023, Emerald Debt Merger Sub L.L.C (“Merger Sub”), a subsidiary of Emerald JV Holdings,
L.P., and which was merged with and into EMRLD Borrower LP (“EMRLD Borrower”) on the Acquisition Date (as
defined below), and Emerald Co-Issuer Inc., a direct subsidiary of Merger Sub (“Co-Issuer,” together with EMRLD
Borrower, the “Issuers”), issued senior secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $2,275.0 and aggregate
principal amount of €455.0 (or $500.0 U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.10 per
€1.00), the “Original Dollar Notes” and “Original Euro Notes”, respectively and collectively the “Original Notes”.


-----

This report includes historical consolidated financial statements and certain financial data of the Company in lieu of
consolidated financial statements and financial data for EMRLD Borrower, the borrower under the Senior Secured
Credit Facilities (defined below) and an issuer of the Notes and the direct subsidiary of EMRLD Guarantor LP
(“Holdings”). The Company does not have any material operating, investing, or financing activities other than being
(i) the issuer of the Preferred Equity and (ii) a holding company for EMRLD Seller Notes Issuer LP (the “Emerson
Notes Issuer”) and Holdings and its subsidiaries. Accordingly, with the exception of the Preferred Equity issued by
the Company (see Note 15 for further details), and the Emerson Notes (defined below) issued by the Emerson Notes
Issuer (see Note 12 for further details), the consolidated Balance Sheet and results of operations of Holdings and its
subsidiaries, including EMRLD Borrower, would be substantially identical to those of the Company and its
subsidiaries for the periods for which financial information is presented in this report.

Prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, Climate Technologies had historically operated as part of Emerson and
not as a standalone entity. The consolidated and combined financial statements for the Predecessor period present the
historical financial position, results of operations, and cash flows of the Company as if it had operated on a standalone
basis subject to Emerson’s control and include all accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries and affiliates on a
consolidated basis. Intercompany transactions, profits and balances among Climate Technologies entities have been
eliminated in consolidation. The Predecessor period consolidated and combined financial statements were derived
from Emerson’s financial statements and accounting records and have been prepared in conformity with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”). Sale and purchase transactions between
the Company and other Emerson affiliates are included in the consolidated financial statements. See Note 16 for
further details.

As a business of Emerson, during the Predecessor period, Climate Technologies was charged for costs directly related
to the Company and has been allocated a portion of Emerson’s general corporate costs. These costs are reflected in
the consolidated and combined financial statements. The Company participated in various Emerson programs which
include information technology services, employee benefits, medical insurance, and other programs. Costs associated
with these programs were charged to the Company based on Emerson’s actual cost and the Company’s relative level
of usage. The Company also utilized Emerson’s global shared service centers and was charged for direct costs and its
share of facilities overhead.

Emerson provided certain oversight and support services, including assistance with management strategy, logistics,
marketing, finance, treasury, tax, human resources, legal and other activities. Emerson also charged royalties for use
of Emerson’s trademarks and trade names and supply chain services. A charge for these services and royalties was
allocated to the Company based principally on revenue. While management believes the methodologies and
assumptions used to allocate these costs were reasonable, the consolidated and combined financial statements for the
Predecessor period do not purport to represent the financial position, or the results of operations, changes in equity,
and cash flows of the Company for the Successor period or in the future, or what they would have been had the
Company operated as a standalone entity during the Predecessor periods presented.

In the opinion of management, the accompanying unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements include
all adjustments necessary for a fair presentation of operating results for the interim periods presented. Adjustments
consist of normal and recurring accruals. The unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements included
herein do not include all disclosures required for interim financial statements presented in conformity with U.S.
GAAP. However, the Company believes that the disclosures are adequate to make the information presented not
misleading. The unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the
audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2023 and the notes thereto. The
Company has applied the same accounting policies between Predecessor and Successor periods. Certain information
has been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.

**_Adopted Accounting Pronouncements_**

In September 2022, the FASB issued ASU 2022-04, “Liabilities - Supplier Finance Program (Subtopic 405-50):
Disclosure of Supplier Program Finance Obligations”, which requires that a company that enters into a supplier finance
program disclose sufficient information about the program to allow a user of financial statements to understand the
program’s nature, activity during the period, changes from period to period, and potential magnitude. To achieve that
objective, the company should disclose qualitative and quantitative information about its supplier finance programs.


-----

The Company early adopted this standard on September 30, 2023, except for the amendment on roll forward
information which is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2023. See Note 10 for more information
regarding the Company’s supplier finance program. There were no new accounting pronouncements adopted during
the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor).

**(2) BUSINESS COMBINATIONS**

**(10) OTHER FINANCIAL INFORMATION**

**_Supplier Finance Program_**

The Company facilitates a voluntary supplier finance program (the “Program”) to provide certain suppliers with the
opportunity to sell receivables due from the Company to the participating financial institution in the Program. Such
sales are conducted at the sole discretion of both the suppliers and the financial institution on a non-recourse basis at
a rate that leverages the Company’s credit rating and thus might be more beneficial to the supplier. The Company’s
responsibility is limited to making payment on the terms originally negotiated with its suppliers, regardless of whether
the suppliers sell their receivables to the financial institution. The amount owed to the participating financial institution
under the Program and included in accounts payable was $114.8 at March 31, 2024 and $92.3 at September 30, 2023.

_Term Loan Credit Agreement_

On May 31, 2023, Merger Sub, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into a credit agreement (the
“Term Loan Credit Agreement”). Upon consummation of the Acquisition on the Closing Date, Merger Sub merged
with and into EMRLD Borrower, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, with EMRLD Borrower surviving such
merger. The Term Loan Credit Agreement permitted the Borrower to borrow $450.0 and $2,275.0 under new senior
secured term loan facilities, the “Term Loan A Facility” and “Original Term Loan B Facility” respectively and
together, the “Original Term Loan Facilities”. On February 6, 2024, EMRLD Borrower entered into an amendment to
the Term Loan Credit Agreement, which provided for the incurrence of a new senior secured term “B” loan (the “New
Term Loan B Facility”) in an aggregate principal amount of $1,519.3, the proceeds of which, together with the
proceeds of the New Notes (defined below) and cash on hand were used to refinance all of the Original Term Loan B


-----

Facility and to pay fees, costs and expenses related to the offering of the New Notes and the New Term Loan B Facility
(the “Refinancing”).

The Term Loan A Facility matures on May 31, 2028 (the “Term Loan A Maturity Date”), and amortizes in quarterly
installments in an amount equal to, (i) commencing with the last business day of the fiscal quarter ending September
30, 2025 and through and including the last business day of the fiscal quarter ending June 30, 2027, 0.625% of the
original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility and (ii) thereafter and through and including the Term Loan A
Maturity Date, of 1.875% of the original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility, with the remaining principal
balance due in a lump sum on the Term Loan A Maturity Date. Borrowings under the Term Loan A Facility bear
interest at an adjusted Term Secured Overnight Financing Rate (“Term SOFR Rate”) plus a margin of between 2.25%
and 2.75% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor
of 0.00%.

The New Term Loan B Facility matures on May 31, 2030 (the “Term Loan B Maturity Date”), and commencing with
the fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2024, amortizes in equal quarterly installments of 0.25% of the original principal
amount of the New Term Loan B Facility, with the remaining principal balance due in a lump sum on the Term Loan
B Maturity Date. Borrowings under the Original Term Loan B Facility bore interest at Term SOFR Rate plus a margin
of between 2.75% and 3.0% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term
SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. Borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility bear interest at the Term SOFR Rate
plus a margin of between 2.25% and 2.50% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio),
subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. Any voluntary prepayment, refinancing or repricing of the term loans
under the New Term Loan B Facility in connection with certain repricing transactions that occur prior to the six-month
anniversary of the closing of the New Term Loan B Facility are subject to a prepayment premium of 1.00% of the
principal amount of such term loans so prepaid, refinanced or repriced, subject to certain exceptions.

In connection with the Original Term Loan Facilities, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $100.3,
which was capitalized and was amortized through interest expense over the term of the Original Term Loan Facilities.
The incurrence of the New Term Loan B Facility coincided with the full extinguishment of the Original Term Loan
B Facility. The Company recognized a loss on debt extinguishment related to the unamortized issuance costs and
discount totaling $96.8 for the period ended March 31, 2024. The New Term Loan B Facility was issued at an Original
Issuance Discount (“OID”) of $1.9. In connection with issuing the New Term Loan B Facility, the Company incurred
and paid debt issuance costs of $1.7 and $1.2, respectively, which was capitalized and is amortized through interest
expense over the respective remaining term of the New Term Loan B Facility. As of March 31, 2024, $17.9 of debt
issuance costs are capitalized for the Term Loan Facilities.

The interest rate in effect for the Term Loan Facilities as of March 31, 2024, was 8.063% and 7.790% for the Term
Loan A Facility and the New Term Loan B Facility, respectively.

Facility.

**(14) SHARE-BASED COMPENSATION**

**Successor Period**

In connection with the Acquisition, the Company created two new incentive plans for its employees’ performance and
retention purposes, the Emerald JV Holdings L.P. 2023 Unit Incentive Plan (“MIP”) and the Long-Term Incentive
Plan (“LTIP”).

During the three and six months ended March 31, 2024, the Company recognized $1.4 and $3.5, respectively, in sharebased compensation expense, which was reported in selling, general and administrative expenses (“SG&A”) in the
condensed consolidated statement of operations. All of this expense related to the Time-Vesting Options (described
further below). There were certain Time-Vesting and Performance-Vesting Options (described further below) granted
and forfeited during the three and six months ended March 31, 2024, described below.

_Long-Term Incentive Plan_

Under the terms of the LTIP, employees are granted awards (the “LTIP Awards”) that become payable upon meeting
both a service condition (the “LTIP Service Condition”) and a liquidity event condition (the “LTIP Liquidity
Condition”). Awards issued under the LTIP have a maximum contractual term of the earlier to occur of the date on
which the vested award amount has been settled or 7 years. LTIP Awards are liability classified since they allow for
settlement in cash at the option of the Company. As of March 31, 2024, the unvested and outstanding Long-Term
Incentive Plan Awards had an aggregate value of $16.1 of unrecognized share-based compensation expense.

_Unit Incentive Plan_

The MIP allows for the issuance of up to 466,881,550 units. Under the terms of the MIP, employees are awarded stock
options (“Options”) or Unit Appreciation Right awards (“UARs”). Awards issued under the MIP have a maximum


-----

contractual term of 10 years. Options under the MIP are equity classified. UARs are liability classified since they
require settlement in cash.

Under the MIP, one half of the Options and UARs will vest in five (5) equal installments on the first through fifth
anniversaries of the vesting commencement date, so long as the employee remains employed by the Company through
the applicable vesting date (“Time-Vesting Units”). One half of the Options and UARs granted under the MIP may
vest upon a liquidity event based on the extent that Blackstone Capital Partners VIII L.P. and its Affiliates (“Sponsor”)
receives cash proceeds in respect of the Sponsor’s original investment in an amount that meets certain multiples on
invested capital and internal rate of return hurdles subject to the recipient’s continued employment at the time the
hurdles are met (“Performance-Vesting Units”). Additionally, with regard to the UARs, both the Time-Vesting Units
and Performance-Vesting Units may only be exercised by an employee following a liquidity event.

_Options_

Compensation expense for the Time-Vesting Units is recognized on a straight-line basis over the five-year requisite
service period. Performance-Vesting Units vest upon the achievement of certain liquidity events which are not
considered probable until consummated and, as such, no compensation expense has been recognized.
