**(15) EQUITY INTERESTS**

**Successor Period**

The unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of equity reflect the issuance of general partner’s interest and
limited partners’ interest in connection of the Acquisition as detailed in Note 2. As of March 31, 2024, the Company
has three main classes of units, General Partner Units, issued to the general partner (“General Partner”), and Class P
Units and Common Units, issued to the limited partners (“Limited Partners”).

_General Partner Units_

The General Partner has the exclusive power and authority to manage and control the business and operations of the
Company. The General Partner is authorized to create additional classes of equity units and can issue an unlimited
number of units of any class. As of March 31, 2024, the Company has a singular issued and outstanding unit of General
Partner Units.

_Limited Partners’ Preferred Equity (Class P Units)_

Class P Units do not contain voting rights (subject to certain standard exceptions) but have priority with respect to
rights on the distribution of assets and dividend upon any voluntary or involuntary liquidation and dissolution. Class
P Units accrete at an amount equal to 7% per annum. The holder of each Class P Unit has the option to, if permitted
by the Class P majority holder, convert the units into Class A-1 Units to participate in tag-along rights of the General
Partner LLC Agreement. In the occurrence of an initial public offering, if the price per share of common stock is
greater than the Conversion Price, all outstanding Class P Units will automatically convert into an aggregate number
of Class A-1 Units, determined by dividing the accreted amount of Class P Units by the Conversion Price (“Mandatory
IPO Conversion”). If an initial public offering occurs but does not meet the conditions for Mandatory IPO Conversion,
the class P majority holder can elect to have all of the Class P Units converted to Class A-1 Units in the same manner
as if a Mandatory IPO Conversion occurs, or, alternatively, can elect to convert the Class P Units into a preferred
security that pays interest at a 9% annual rate in cash, on the terms and conditions set forth in the Company’s limited
partnership agreement. Upon a change in control or when the holder of Class P Unit elects to participate in tag-along
rights, the Class P Units will automatically convert into Class A-1 Units in the amount equal to the greater of the
accreted amount of Class P Units divided by the price per Class A-1 Unit or Conversion Price. The Company has 2.0
million Class P Units issued and outstanding as of March 31, 2024.

_Conversion Price_

The “Conversion Price” for the Class P Units will be calculated as the product of 1.10 and the common equity
consideration in connection with the Acquisition divided by the number of Class A-1 Units acquired by BCP Ruby
Limited Partners. The initial and current Conversion Price for the Class P Units is $1.1 per share. The Conversion
Price is subject to adjustment upon the occurrence of certain anti-dilutive common stock events, including stock splits,
the issuance of common stock dividends.

_Limited Partners’ Common Equity (Common Units)_

Common Units consist of Class A-1 Units and Class A-2 Units. The Class A-2 Units are issued to management and
do not contain voting rights. Common Units rank subsequent to holders of Class P units in any distributions or
dividends. During the six months ended March 31, 2024, 1.0 million Class A-2 units were issued to management for
$1.0. As of March 31, 2024, the Company has approximately 4,201.9 million Class A-1 units and 3.0 million Class
A-2 units issued and outstanding.

**(17) CONTINGENT LIABILITIES AND COMMITMENTS**

The Company is a party to a number of pending legal proceedings and claims, including those involving general and
product liability (including asbestos), and other matters. The Company accrues for such liabilities when it is probable
that future costs will be incurred and such costs can be reasonably estimated. Accruals are based on developments to
date; management’s estimates of the outcomes of these matters; the Company’s experience in contesting, litigating
and settling similar matters; and any related insurance coverage. While the Company believes a material adverse
impact is unlikely, it is not possible to predict the ultimate outcome of these matters. Given the inherent uncertainty
of litigation, a remote possibility exists that a future development could have a material adverse impact on the
Company.

The Company engages an outside expert to develop an actuarial estimate of its expected costs to resolve all pending
and future asbestos claims, including defense costs, as well as its related insurance receivable. The reserve for asbestos
litigation, which is recorded on an undiscounted basis, was $53.8 and the insurance receivable was $26.3 as of both
March 31, 2024 (Successor) and September 30, 2023 (Successor). As part of the Transaction Agreement, Emerson
has indemnified the Company for asbestos liabilities up to $75.0; with Emerson having the right to offset any such
amount against the Emerson Notes. The Company anticipates the total amount of claims filed during the 7-year period
will be $28.5 with a related insurance receivable of $10.0, and therefore an indemnification receivable equal to $18.5
has been recorded as of both September 30, 2023 and March 31, 2024.

The Company is also responsible for environmental remediation at various facilities presently or formerly operated
by the Company. The environmental remediation liability is recorded based upon the best estimate of costs to be
incurred in light of the progress made in determining the magnitude of remediation costs, the timing, and extent of
remedial actions required by governmental authorities. The actual costs the Company will incur are dependent on final
determination of contamination and required remedial action, negotiations with governmental authorities with respect
to cleanup levels, changes in regulatory requirements, innovations in investigatory and remedial technologies,
effectiveness of remedial technologies employed, the ability of other responsible parties to pay, and any insurance or
other third-party recoveries. As of March 31, 2024 (Successor) the Company has recorded, on an undiscounted basis,
a total liability of $15.9 for environmental remediation-and related legal costs regarding these facilities.
Approximately $3.3 and $12.6 was recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively. As of
September 30, 2023 (Successor), the Company has recorded, on an undiscounted basis, a total liability of $16.6 for


-----

environmental remediation-and related legal costs regarding these facilities. Approximately $3.7 and $12.9 was
recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively.

As of March 31, 2024 (Successor), there were no other known contingent liabilities (including guarantees and other
claims) that management believes will be material in relation to the Company’s financial statements, nor were there
any material commitments outside the normal course of business.
